headline: Coordination Group on Venezuela Meeting Readout
entry:
• Convened by: Laura Flores, Director of the Americas Division, DPPA, UN Coordinator for Venezuela 

  •  Context: This coordination role was established following the decision of the Extraordinary EC on 5 January. 

  • Purpose of the Meeting: To review the current political and humanitarian situation in Venezuela and coordinate UN system engagement in light of ongoing developments. 

The Coordination Group on Venezuela (CGV) was established following the 5 January meeting of the Executive Committee, which decided that DPPA would designate a senior official at the D2 level to coordinate UN cross-pillar action in Venezuela, to pave the way for an inclusive political transition, in close consultation with the Resident Coordinator and UNCT. DPPA designated the Americas Division Director to play this coordinating role. The Group will serve as the principal Headquarters mechanism for UN inter-departmental and inter-agency coordination of strategic guidance and information exchange on the situation in Venezuela. It will also monitor the political, security, humanitarian, development and human rights situation in Venezuela; exchange analysis, identify UN priorities and make recommendations for strategic engagement.  
 
Meeting minutes: 
·      The Director of the Americas Division (AD) shared that the Secretary-General has offered his good offices to support an inclusive political process, which is critical to healing divisions among Venezuelans and achieving lasting stability. To that end, he held meetings with the Permanent Representative of Venezuela and of the United States. The Permanent Representative of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela invited the Secretary-General to visit the country. The Secretary-General has accepted the invitation but has designated DPPA to represent him. DPPA will coordinate the visit of a technical mission led by a senior official. AD stressed that the Secretary-General is not considering a Personal Envoy at this moment, and the exchanges within the Group will also inform aspects of the visit and future engagement. AD recalled that the Secretary-General has underscored, the gravity of the situation in Venezuela and called a coherent, system-wide UN response, emphasizing that the UN must remain consistent with its principles and play a constructive role. He also called for full alignment across all pillars to prioritize humanitarian and operational continuity, strengthen human rights protection, promote peacebuilding, and, eventually, ensure technical readiness for credible elections, reaffirming that the UN’s guiding principle is to support Venezuelans in shaping their own future while safeguarding the Organization’s neutrality and integrity. The Secretary-General has also noted that resource mobilization should remain needs-based and low-profile to avoid perceptions of political alignment. The focus should remain on humanitarian continuity, recovery projects, and support to local communities. 
 
·      Regarding the situation in Venezuela, AD highlighted that acting President Rodríguez has moved quickly to normalize state functions and project continuity after the US operation. She has signaled guarded readiness to engage with Washington and has started a “diplomatic exploratory process” with the United States to re-establish diplomatic representations in both capitals, while aiming to balance internal political tensions. Initial senior government appointments have signaled continuity. While there is being progress in the release of detainees, from 800 political prisoners according to human rights groups, only about 60 appear to have been released thus far. AD briefly described the US three-phase plan (stabilization, recovery, and transition) and uncensored that credible elections would require reforms, including in electoral bodies and the judiciary, as well as political agreements. 
 
·      The Resident Coordinator provided an overview of the evolving situation on the ground, underscoring the delicate balance in the relationship between the government and the US. He highlighted the recent meeting of the Acting President with EU Member States, the UK and Switzerland, as a sign of openness, as well as the attitude of Minister of Interior, who has aimed to display alignment with acting President. Despite the ongoing liberation of detainees, precautionary measures in place, structural challenges remain, and foreign correspondents are no allowed to access to the country. The authorities continue to communicate that their priority remain the liberation of President Maduro, continued negotiations with the US and political and security control of the territory. The RC stressed that the State of Emergency, which entered into force on 5 January, is not being fully implemented, as this would significantly undermine the free movement of UN operations across the country and across the borders. For the UN, support to the social agenda, human rights and institutionalization remain key priorities. He stressed that it is the moment to push for OHCHR's return. Regarding upcoming missions to the country, the RC called for a sequenced and strategic approach, with the SG-delegated mission coming first, and requested the alignment of communication engagement, with harmonized UN messaging and calls. 
 
·      Human Rights: OHCHR highlighted High Commissioner Türk’s involvement on the Venezuela issue and stressed that the situation offers an opportunity to reaffirm the centrality of human rights. OHCHR regretted that prisoner releases have been conditional, with those released not able to speak publicly, and underscored that pressure continue for the continuation of releases, without conditions. Emergency measures and longer-term institutional reforms as well as the protection of civic space must prioritized according to OHCHR, as vital for the transition. OHCHR announced that HC Türk has requested to speak with HC has requested to speak to President Rodriguez. The DHC met with the Venezuelan Permanent Representative in Geneva and OHCHR seek to engage further and will continue advocating for the return of the team to Venezuela. A technical human rights mission could follow the DPPA visit, which should also address the human rights situation. 
 
·      Migration: UNHCR addressed the human mobility angle and reported no movements in border crossing to Colombia and Brazil. The most likely scenario is continued forced returns from the US and Latin American countries. The change in government in Chile was mentioned as an example which may trigger additional non-voluntary returns. UNHCR highlighted that funding remains an issue. Potential US financial support to humanitarian operations through OCHA should be explored. UNHCR also called for the Group’s support in advocating to address visa restrictions undermining humanitarian operations. IOM also participated and underscored closed coordination with UNHCR. DCO called for close consultations with RCs across the region, to ensure a common regional approach on human mobility 
 
·      Humanitarian access: UNICEF reported increased controls and discretionary administrative practices in states bordering Colombia and Caracas, as well as arbitrary detentions and subsequent release of adolescence. OCHA underscored the importance of ensuring continuity of the humanitarian response and reported no confirmation of additional US humanitarian funding. The RC stressed that the Working group on access continues to monitor the situation and has not identified obstacles compromising humanitarian access. On existing obstacles in the obtention of visas for humanitarian workers, the RC acknowledged that the backlog continues but there are expectations of improvement.   
 
·      International Financial Institutions: As highlighted by the EC decision, engagement with IFIs, once political conditions allow, could be an avenue to reinforce institution-building, governance reforms, and anti-corruption safeguards. Cooperation with IFIs was described as critical by the RC, following 15 years of absence of the World Bank from the country. It was agreed that the UN should engage with IFIs in the definition of their strategies to support reconstruction once conditions allow. PBSO offered to liaise with IFIs in this process. 
 
·      Peacebuilding: support through PBF, despite limited resources, could be explored if UN requirements were met. 
 
·      Development: DCO offered to deploy surge capacity if needed, as well as to mobilize the RCP capacities to support UN engagement in Venezuela. 
 
·      Communications: as media interest on the matter gradually decreases, the Spokesperson’s office offered to host the RC as a noon briefing guest to highlight the humanitarian and development needs in the country. 
 
·      Electoral support: EAD highlighted that significant institutional and legal aspects must be addressed ahead of an electoral process – the 2024 Panel of Experts Report, available internally for consultation, features useful recommendations. Changing the composition of the CNE and the Supreme Court were mentioned as examples of significant reforms which would also send a powerful political message. 
 
·      Drugs and crime: UNODC highlighted that cooperation will continue to be overseen by their office in Colombia. Coordination with the RC is ongoing for a potential technical level mission, particularly relevant as anti-drug policies will remain at the top of the political agenda and a priority for the US engagement in the country. 
 
·      UN neutrality: OLA underscored the need to remain neutral and avoid any form of engagement which may appear to be legitimizing the US intervention, which, as stated by the Secretary-General did not comply with international law. 
 
Next steps:  

The RC highlighted that the current context poses an opportunity to foster intra-Venezuelan dialogue and push for reforms that can lead to a transition. This will require identifying meaningful spaces for UN engagement, including through in-country missions, as well as continued engagement with national stakeholders and key external ones, including Türkiye, Qatar, Brazil, or Colombia. Direct engagement of the Secretary-General with the Venezuelan authorities was also mentioned as a potential enabler ahead of the DPPA mission. 
  

DPPA, together with the Group will: 
- Re-Convene this meeting, and invite other agencies and offices, as needed, initially every 2 weeks. 
- Engage with the Government to ensure OHCHR´s presence in Venezuela. 
- Coordinate UN missions to the country in a sequenced and strategic way. 
- Harmonize communication efforts and organize a noon briefing session with the RC. 
- Advocate for continued humanitarian access. 
- Explore engagement with IFIs.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: President Petro Seeks to Enlist Donald Trump and Delcy Rodríguez in His Fight Against the ELN Guerrilla (El Pais, 12 Jan)
entry:
• Colombia agrees with the United States on “joint actions” against the armed group, which has a strong presence in Venezuela 

  • The Catatumbo War Intensifies, Overshadowed by U.S. Intervention in Venezuela (El Pais, 12 Jan) 

The reconciliation between Colombian President Petro and U.S. President Trump has given new momentum to Colombia’s fight against the National Liberation Army (ELN), one of the country’s most powerful armed and drug-trafficking groups. Founded in the 1960s, the ELN has expanded its military, economic, and territorial control in recent years following the collapse of peace talks. 

A recent call between Petro and Trump marks a shift in their previously tense relationship and positions Washington as a key ally in Colombia’s renewed offensive. While neither government has detailed how cooperation will unfold, analysts suggest it could evolve into a tripartite strategy involving the United States and Venezuela, aimed at containing a group deeply entrenched in eastern Colombia and across the Venezuelan border. 

Petro has reinforced his hard-line stance, declaring on X that “drug traffickers must be disarmed,” and calling for regional unity against destabilizing actors. In the same X post, Petro also urged Venezuela’s interim president, Delcy Rodríguez, to work jointly toward that goal. 

Conflict analyst Jorge Mantilla says the government’s announcements open a significant window of opportunity, despite the ELN’s growing sophistication, including the use of drones, thermal sensors, and an expanded urban presence. According to Mantilla, the group’s worst-case scenario would be a rapid political transition in Venezuela that seriously targets armed groups—though no such shift appears imminent. 

The ELN has operated in Venezuela for years, forging ties with local authorities and security forces and acting as a de facto authority in several regions, complicating any effort by the Chavista leadership to dismantle it. InSight Crime co-director Jeremy McDermott outlines three possible scenarios: no change in the ELN’s status, symbolic measures under U.S. pressure, or—least likely—meaningful action to expel the group from Venezuelan territory. 

Armed groups appear increasingly alarmed by U.S. involvement. In a recent video, FARC dissident leader Iván Mordisco called for a criminal alliance, including the ELN, to confront what he described as U.S. “imperialist aggression” in Venezuela. 

Experts agree that peace talks with the ELN are effectively over: Petro’s “total peace” strategy has steadily eroded, and with his term nearing its end, the president appears focused on restoring ties with Washington to avoid future judicial or financial repercussions once out of office. 

Clashes between the ELN guerrilla group and FARC dissidents—already responsible for more than 85,000 displaced people—have flared up again during the holidays and has not fully subsidised in 2026. “The 33rd Front of the Calarcá dissidents—currently in peace talks with the government—as well as the ELN, continue to dispute territory without any regard for the civilian population,” said Colombia’s Ombudsman.

headline: Trump to meet Venezuelan opposition leader Machado at the White House (BBC, 13 January)
entry:
In this context, Venezuelan opposition leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner María Corina Machado will meet President Donald Trump on Thursday, the White House has confirmed. 

Machado said last week she hoped to thank Trump personally for the action against Maduro and would like to give the Nobel Prize to him. Trump called it "a great honour", but the Nobel Committee later clarified that it was not transferable. 

Earlier, Trump had expressed displeasure over Machado's decision to accept the Nobel Peace Prize, an honour the president has long coveted. 

Asked on Friday whether receiving Machado's prize might change his view of her role in Venezuela, the president said: "She might be involved in some aspect of it." 

"I will have to speak to her. I think it's very nice that she wants to come in. And that's what I understand the reason is," he said. 

Earlier this month, after Maduro's ouster, Trump had said Machado "doesn't have the support within, or the respect within, the country". "She's a very nice woman, but she doesn't have the respect," he said. 

The US has so far backed Delcy Rodríguez as Venezuela's interim president. 

Trump describes Rodríguez as an "ally", and she has not been charged by US officials with any crimes. 

"Delcy Rodríguez and her team have been very cooperative with the United States," White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said on Monday. 

But Machado has maintained that her coalition should "absolutely" be in charge of the country. 

Machado has said nobody trusted Rodríguez, telling CBS that the interim leader was "one of the main architects... of repression for innocent people" in the South American country. "Everybody in Venezuela and abroad knows perfectly who she is and the role she has played," Machado said. 

The former legislator, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize last year, described US military action in Venezuela as "a major step towards restoring prosperity and rule of law and democracy in Venezuela". 

Rodríguez has rebuffed claims by Trump that the US was in charge of Venezuela. "The Venezuelan government rules our country, and no-one else does," she said in a televised speech. "There is no external agent governing Venezuela."
author: Gregoria Verity
ai_summary: ["María Corina Machado will meet with President Trump to discuss Venezuela's leadership situation and express gratitude for U.S. actions.","President Trump praised Machado's gesture regarding the Nobel Prize but expressed prior reservations about her respect and influence in Venezuela.","The U.S. officially supports Delcy Rodríguez as Venezuela's interim leader, with Trump describing her as an \"ally\" cooperative with U.S. efforts.","Machado criticized Rodríguez as a key architect of repression and asserted her coalition's legitimacy to govern Venezuela.","Rodríguez rejected claims of U.S. control over Venezuela, emphasizing the sovereignty of its government in a televised statement."]

headline: Gaza technocratic committee set to meet in Egyptian capital this week: Palestinian source (AA, Asharq al Awsat, SkyNews, 14 Jan)
entry:
Arrangements are underway for members of a technocratic committee tasked with administering the Gaza Strip to travel from the enclave to Egypt to hold their first meeting on Thursday or Friday, a Palestinian source told Anadolu. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said committee members have been formally notified of their appointment and will begin work within their respective portfolios once the panel convenes. Citing four officials and six people familiar with the matter, The New York Times reported late Tuesday that the United States is close to announcing the committee’s formation, with Ali Shaath expected to chair it.  

The source  told Asharq Al-Awsat that the 18-member committee will be comprised of Gaza residents who are businessmen, academics or involved in civil society. 

No immediate official comment was issued by the Palestinian Authority, Egypt or the US regarding the meeting. The committee includes academic, professional and community figures selected for their technical expertise to manage Gaza’s most urgent sectors in response to the scale of the humanitarian crisis in the territory, the source and Palestinian media said.  

A Palestinian source said that the budget of the technocratic committee will be independent and will be sourced from donor countries and directly supervised by the international committee headed by Nickolay Mladenov. He added: "The protocol of the committee and the names of its members will be signed by Shaath and Mladenov within days. The form of renouncing and dealing with terrorism will be signed by each member of the committee." 

Separately, the Financial Times and other outlets report that several people involved in the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF) are poised to play central roles in a new international committee (Led by Nikolay Mladenov) for Gaza under a U.S.-led “Board of Peace”. 

 

- Committee members 

 

Ali Shaath, a former Palestinian deputy planning minister, is expected to chair the committee, local sources and Palestinian and international media said, citing his background in planning, development and infrastructure.
pu_note: PU note: Former deputy minister in the Palestinian Authority (PA), which is dominated by Fatah. Lives in the West Bank but originally from Gaza. Inferred PA/Fatah alignment. However, the committee members are independent technocrats with no known political affiliation, at least publicly.
author: Gregoria Verity
ai_summary: ["Members of a technocratic committee for Gaza will convene in Egypt this week to begin administrative coordination for the enclave.","The 18-member committee, chaired by Ali Shaath, comprises Gaza-based academics, professionals, and civil society leaders.","The committee's independent budget will be sourced from international donors and supervised by an international body led by Nickolay Mladenov.","The U.S. is expected to announce the committee's formation, with members selected for technical expertise to address the humanitarian crisis.","Formal protocols, including commitments to counter terrorism, will be signed by committee members and international officials in the coming days."]

headline: Costa Rica’s security director says plot to assassinate president uncovered
entry:
Costa Rica’s national security chief on Tuesday revealed details of an alleged plot to assassinate President Rodrigo Chaves ahead of presidential and legislative elections. 

Jorge Torres, director of the Intelligence and National Security Directorate, told journalists about the plot allegations as he prepared to file a formal complaint at the public prosecutor’s office. 

“What we received is confidential information that I would like to put on record in the complaint. I don’t want to go into detail, but I would simply like to tell you that it concerns the life of the president of the Republic,” Torres told local media. 

Torres said a call was received from a woman who reported a supposed plot against Chaves, adding that a payment had been made to a hitman. He also reported that security was being reinforced for the conservative populist leader, who has sought to present himself as a politician who is tough on crime. 

Torres spoke as El Salvador’s President Nayib Bukele, who has gained international attention for his controversial security crackdown, was scheduled to visit the country. 

On Wednesday, Chaves is scheduled to lay the cornerstone of a new mega-prison that Costa Rica plans to build, modeled on a facility constructed by Bukele. 

Costa Rica will hold presidential and legislative elections on Feb. 1. While Chaves is ineligible to run for reelection, the ruling party’s Laura Fernández is among the presidential candidates.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: How much is China willing to risk to protect its ties with Iran? - China is weighing how far it is willing to go to protect its economic relationship with Iran as the United States threatens new tariffs on countries that defy Washington’s line on Tehran. (RFI, 01/16)
entry:
As protests and repression intensify inside Iran, Beijing finds itself under growing pressure. China’s long-standing principle of non-interference is colliding with its deep economic entanglement with the Islamic Republic. When US President Donald Trump warned that Tehran would face “serious consequences” if protesters were killed, China initially stayed silent. When it did respond, it repeated familiar positions, calling for calm, opposing outside interference and restating views it said it had “always” held. That posture shifted on Tuesday, when Trump announced an additional 25 percent tariff on countries that continue to defy Washington’s policy on Iran. The measure was to take effect “definitively” and “immediately”, and was aimed above all at China, Iran’s most important trading partner. Beijing said it would “resolutely defend its legitimate rights and interests”, reject foreign military intervention in Iran and act as needed to protect Chinese citizens. 

 

Trade and oil ties 

China is central to Iran’s economy. More than a quarter of Iran’s total trade in 2024 was conducted with China, according to the World Trade Organization. Iran imported around $18 billion worth of goods from China and exported about $14.5 billion in return, figures that underline the scale of the partnership. Chinese energy companies, including Sinopec, are directly involved in offshore oil extraction in Iranian waters. China was still importing an estimated 1.8 million barrels of Iranian oil per day last autumn. “These oil flows fluctuate depending on the month,” said Théo Nencini, a researcher specialising in Sino-Iranian relations at the Catholic Institute of Paris and Sciences Po Grenoble. 

“They increase with the Chinese New Year. In general, between December and January – not always – the Chinese import a little less, then imports rise just after.” Nencini said a key shift came in March 2023, when Iran and Saudi Arabia restored diplomatic relations in Beijing. “From that moment on, we saw a fairly dizzying increase in Iranian oil exports to China,” he said. Until 2022, exports averaged around 700,000 to 800,000 barrels per day. “Then it rose to around 1.5 million in 2025.”
pu_note:
Iran is now a key link in Xi Jinping’s Belt and Road strategy, connecting Central Asia to the Arabian Gulf. China has also acted as a broker between Iran and Saudi Arabia when strategic, particularly energy, interests align. 

 

Support, but with limits 

Beijing’s support for Tehran is not unconditional. Chaudet said Iranian perceptions of Russia and China are increasingly diverging. “Moscow has not lived up to the expected level of support,” he said, despite Tehran’s alignment with the Kremlin over Ukraine. China, however, “is not in a position of absolute support”, Chaudet said. Chinese analysts are aware of the Iranian regime’s weaknesses and are “not receptive” to Tehran’s calls for greater assistance. “Iran is a partner, certainly, but not at the heart of China’s national interests,” he said. “China will not go into conflict with Washington to save Tehran.” 

What remains central for Beijing is keeping oil flowing through the Strait of Hormuz. “The Chinese are waiting,” Nencini said. “They are waiting to see how everyone reacts.” Whether Washington’s threat of secondary tariffs will divert China from Iranian oil remains uncertain, particularly given the fragile trade truce between the two countries. Much now depends on Trump’s next move. He has said his only limit is his own “moral compass”, alongside domestic political pressure and looming mid-term elections.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Chad’s Déby wins 2026 African Peace Prize for role in Sudan refugee crisis (Africanews, 17 January)
entry: Chadian President Mahamat Idriss Déby Itno has been named the winner of the 2026 African Peace Prize for his peaceful management of Chad's political transition and the country's humanitarian response to Sudanese refugees, the African Conference for Peace has announced. The Prize Committee's unanimous decision recognizes President Déby’s role in consolidating peace in Chad while opening the country's eastern border to hundreds of thousands of people fleeing conflict in Sudan, the organization said. The committee met at the United Nations headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, under the auspices of the UN-mandated University for Peace (UPEACE), and was chaired by Dr. David Fernández Puyana and attended by Cheikh Al-Mahfoudh Bin Bayyah, along with legal experts, human rights defenders, and international diplomats. In a statement, the committee said its decision followed an in-depth review of nominations and analytical reports by African and international research centers, highlighting President Déby's efforts to strengthen national unity and use dialogue as a strategic tool for resolving political and regional disputes. Since coming to power, Déby has sought to reconcile different political and social groups in Chad, promote national reconciliation and combat extremism and cross-border crime, with the committee noting that he steered a sensitive political transition without the country descending into violence. On the humanitarian front, reports from the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) and aid organizations in eastern Chad have praised the government's decision to keep borders open to Sudanese refugees, after President Déby ordered the unconditional opening of border crossings and the creation of humanitarian corridors in areas including Adré, Tiné, Kornoy, Um Dukhun, Wadi Hawar and Amdjarass, and urged local communities to host the displaced. Data cited by the committee indicate that between 40% and 45% of the refugees have been absorbed into host communities, with villages in eastern Chad sharing homes, wells and schools without compensation—solidarity that led the United Nations to describe Chad as "a rare model of African generosity toward refugees despite limited resources," crediting the rapid border opening and flexible stance with helping to save hundreds of thousands of lives. The committee said the award aligns with the mission of the African Peace Prize, which honors leaders who embody high human values, spread a culture of peace, strengthen security and support sustainable development, in line with the African Union's Agenda 2063, "The Africa We Want." Previous laureates include Niger's President Mohamed Bazoum (2022), Nigeria's then-President Muhammadu Buhari (2023), Gambian President Adama Barrow (2024) and Ivorian President Alassane Ouattara (2025). […] The award ceremony is scheduled for early February in Nouakchott, during the opening session of the 6th African Conference for Peace, where Mauritanian President Mohamed Ould Cheikh El Ghazouani will present the prize to President Déby.
pu_note: PU Note: While the award highlights genuine humanitarian contributions and aligns with the African Union’s stability goals, it faces criticism for irony given persistent allegations – supported by UN reports and analysts – that Déby's government has allowed UAE arms shipments through Chad to the RSF, potentially prolonging the conflict driving the refugee crisis. Initial reactions to the announcement on X include mockery of the prize’s legitimacy and accusations of hypocrisy. Overall, the award has limited significance beyond symbolic recognition of refugee hosting, undermined by unresolved controversies over Chad’s role in the Sudan war.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Doha and shipping giant MSC take charge of Misrata port (Africa Intelligence, 14 Jan)
entry:
After many months of particularly intense negotiations, Libya's Misurata Free Zone Authority (MFZ) has finally made its decision. Its operations will be handled by a consortium formed by the world's leading maritime freight company, the Italian-Swiss Mediterranean Shipping Co (MSC), and the infrastructure investment fund Maha Capital Partners, backed by the sovereign wealth fund Qatar Investment Authority (QIA). The container terminal at Libya's largest port, located 200km east of Tripoli, will now be under their responsibility. 

 

The Italian-Qatari consortium will invest $1.5bn to modernise the port and logistics sector. The concession contract signing ceremony is scheduled for 18 January in Misrata and is expected to be co-chaired by very senior figures. The Prime Minister of the Tripoli-based Government of National Unity (GNU), Abdul Hamid Dbeibeh, is expected to attend, despite his hospitalisation at the start of January. Also due to attend are the Prime Minister of Qatar, Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani, and the Italian Prime Minister, Giorgia Meloni, or one of her representatives, to formalise this record-breaking deal. 

 

Long-standing partners 

The goal of Mediterranean Shipping Co and Maha Capital Partners is not only to modernise the existing port of Misrata, but also to develop and build a new deep-water port. 

 

The future management of the site was the subject of a fierce battle throughout last year between two Turkish groups, YilPort Holding and Albayrak, and two Emirati groups, Abu Dhabi Ports and DP World. The French group from Marseille, CMA CGM, was also in the running to win this contract. Africa Global Logistics (formerly Bolloré Africa Logistics, a subsidiary of MSC) had decided to pull out of this market a few years ago, after losing the contract to operate the MFZ container terminals, which it had won in 2010. 

 

The name of the winners is no great surprise. Following the fall of Muammar Gaddafi in 2011, the Qataris have been staunch supporters of Dbeibeh's GNU, which has been in office since 2021. For their part, the United Arab Emirates have thrown their support behind Khalifa Haftar, who controls the east of the country. As for Meloni, she has taken particular care to nurture her relations with Libya, where she has travelled several times since coming to power in 2022.
pu_note: PU note: This deal significantly strengthens the Tripoli-based GNU by placing Libya’s largest commercial port under the control of a consortium backed by Qatar (a long-time backer of the Tripoli-based GNU government) and Italy (pursuing stronger ties for migration control, energy, and economic influence in Libya), two of the GNU’s key supporters, while sidelining rival bidders linked to Türkiye, and the UAE thereby reshaping the balance of foreign influence in western Libya. It also gives the GNU greater economic leverage, boosts its international legitimacy, and anchors European and Qatari strategic interests in Libya’s Mediterranean trade corridor at a time when control over ports directly translates into political power, regional influence, and leverage over migration, energy, and security dynamics. The presence of top leaders at the signing emphasizes its importance and diplomatic weight.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Gulf states urge US not to strike Iran
entry:
Gulf states led by Saudi Arabia are reportedly urging Washington not to strike Iran, warning of energy and domestic stability risks; Riyadh has told Tehran it will stay out of any conflict and not provide airspace for US strikes, according to the reporting (14 Jan 2026, MEMO/Al Jazeera/Daily Sabah/WSJ).  

·       US President Trump signaled a potential cooling of military options after being told killings and executions had halted, even as evacuations from regional bases and allied advisories continued (14 Jan 2026, Al Jazeera; 14 Jan 2026, Al Monitor).  

·       Iran temporarily closed its airspace to most traffic amid tensions, allowing only pre-approved international civil flights (14 Jan 2026, Shafaq/Jerusalem Post/Anadolu).  

·       Commentary argues Iran’s crisis tests BRICS cohesion, noting muted or order-focused reactions by China, Russia and others, and framing the unrest as a structural challenge to governance and economics (14 Jan 2026, MEMO).  

  • The US announced 25% tariffs targeting countries that continue to do business with Iran, affecting regional economies and firms (14 Jan 2026, The New Arab).  

External positioning has become a central variable. Saudi Arabia, joined by Qatar and Oman, is reported to be pressing Washington to avoid strikes due to energy and domestic stability concerns, while conveying to Tehran that Riyadh would not permit US use of its airspace—steps meant to avoid entanglement (14 Jan 2026, MEMO/Al Jazeera/Daily Sabah).  Concurrently, the United States signaled tactical recalibration as President Trump said he had been told killings and executions had stopped, even as regional force protection measures and airspace cautions persisted (14 Jan 2026, Al Jazeera; 14 Jan 2026, Al Monitor).  Iran’s authorities announced a temporary closure of national airspace to most flights, indicative of heightened threat perceptions and an attempt to manage escalation risks (14 Jan 2026, Shafaq/Jerusalem Post/Anadolu).  Strategically, the unrest is framed as a stress test for BRICS and a challenge to narratives of multipolar governance, with member reactions emphasizing sovereignty and non-interference over explicit censure—highlighting divergence within the bloc (14 Jan 2026, MEMO).  Analytical scenarios range from intensified repression and potential IRGC-centered outcomes to limited elite reshuffles and debates over foreign intervention; opposition figure Reza Pahlavi’s visibility has increased, though this is not equated with consensus (14 Jan 2026, The New Arab).  Separately, new US tariff measures threaten to raise the economic cost for regional partners trading with Iran, potentially reinforcing Tehran’s isolation while complicating regional supply chains (14 Jan 2026, The New Arab).
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Public impeachment hearings against President Lai Ching-te (WPR, 01/14)
entry:
Public impeachment hearings began today in Taiwan’s opposition-controlled legislature against President Lai Ching-te. While the effort to remove Lai from office is almost certain to fail given the opposition lacks the necessary two-thirds majority, it illustrates the deep polarization that is besetting Taiwan and threatening Lai’s efforts to bolster the island’s defenses against miliary threats from China. 

The impeachment bid stems from a dispute over legislative amendments passed in November that would have required a greater share of public funds be allocated to local governments. In an unprecedented move, Lai’s administration refused to implement the law, arguing it would be fiscally ruinous for the country and require an unconstitutional level of lending to make up the shortfall. 

Amid what some analysts are calling a constitutional crisis, the Legislative Yuan—where the opposition KMT and its smaller ally, the Taiwan People’s Party or TPP, hold a majority of seats—initiated impeachment proceedings, denouncing Lai as an “emperor.” It is only the second time a sitting Taiwanese president has been impeached.
author: Gregoria Verity
ai_summary: ["Taiwan’s legislature began impeachment hearings against President Lai Ching-te, highlighting deep political polarization and constitutional tensions.","The opposition's effort to remove Lai is unlikely to succeed, lacking the required two-thirds legislative majority.","Lai’s refusal to implement a fiscal law, deemed unconstitutional and financially damaging, sparked impeachment efforts and legal disputes.","Opposition parties, KMT and TPP, control the Legislative Yuan and accuse Lai of undermining democratic governance.","This historic impeachment marks only the second instance of a sitting Taiwanese president facing removal proceedings."]

headline: Denmark / Greenland
entry:
• Denmark and Greenland held talks with senior U.S. officials in Washington aimed at reducing tensions over U.S. President Donald Trump’s stated desire to control Greenland, but Danish and Greenlandic officials said the American position remained unchanged and sovereignty demands were unacceptable (14 Jan 2026, Politico). 

  • Germany, France, Sweden, and Norway announced plans to send military personnel to Greenland at Denmark’s request to explore possible security contributions, as President Trump intensified rhetoric about U.S. ownership of the territory and cited concerns about Russia and China (14 Jan 2026, Reuters). 

Relations between Denmark, Greenland, and the United States have entered a period of acute tension following renewed and explicit assertions by U.S. President Donald Trump that Washington should acquire control of Greenland. Danish Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen and Greenlandic Foreign Minister Vivian Motzfeldt met senior U.S. officials in Washington in an effort to de-escalate the dispute, but both officials stated publicly that the talks failed to alter the U.S. position (14 Jan 2026, Politico). Rasmussen said there remains a “fundamental disagreement” with the United States and emphasized that any demands violating Danish or Greenlandic sovereignty are “totally unacceptable.” He further stated that President Trump continues to express a wish to “conquer” Greenland, a stance that Denmark and Greenland made clear was not in the interest of the Kingdom (14 Jan 2026, Politico). 
Despite the failure to shift U.S. policy, the parties agreed to establish high-level working groups to explore possible paths forward, although Rasmussen expressed uncertainty about whether these mechanisms would produce results (14 Jan 2026, Politico). Danish officials also criticized what they described as inaccurate U.S. claims regarding the security environment in Greenland, including assertions that Russian and Chinese warships are routinely present in the Arctic. Rasmussen stated that there has not been a Chinese warship in the Arctic for a decade and argued that threatening rhetoric undermines constructive dialogue (14 Jan 2026, Politico). 
The dispute has taken on a pronounced military and alliance dimension. Rasmussen disclosed that Denmark has contributed approximately $15 billion to Arctic security over the past two years and has pressed the United States and other NATO allies to increase their engagement through the alliance (14 Jan 2026, Politico). Denmark also announced plans to strengthen its own security presence in Greenland, underscoring Copenhagen’s intent to reinforce sovereignty and deterrence amid escalating U.S. pressure (14 Jan 2026, Politico). On the same day, President Trump publicly linked his demand for control of Greenland to the proposed U.S. “Golden Dome” missile defense project, asserting that NATO should facilitate U.S. acquisition of the territory and warning that Russia or China would otherwise do so (14 Jan 2026, Politico). 
European allies have responded by signaling concrete military support for Denmark. Germany and France stated they would send military personnel to Greenland, while Sweden and Norway separately announced similar deployments (14 Jan 2026, Reuters). Germany confirmed that a 13-member reconnaissance team would deploy from Thursday to Saturday to assess conditions and explore potential military contributions to support Denmark in ensuring regional security, including possible maritime surveillance roles (14 Jan 2026, Reuters). The German government emphasized that the mission was undertaken at Denmark’s request and in coordination with other European partners. 
These European deployments reflect growing concern within Europe about the implications of U.S. rhetoric and the stability of transatlantic relations. President Trump has repeatedly asserted that Greenland is strategically vital to U.S. security and has stated that all options remain on the table to secure the territory, language that European officials say has severely strained relations between the United States and its allies (14 Jan 2026, Reuters). Denmark and Greenland, while seeking continued dialogue, have publicly reinforced that sovereignty is non-negotiable and that security concerns should be addressed through alliance cooperation rather than territorial acquisition (14 Jan 2026, Politico).

ai_summary: ["Denmark and Greenland rejected President Trump’s renewed push to acquire Greenland, emphasizing non-negotiable sovereignty and alliance-based security cooperation.","Talks between Danish, Greenlandic, and U.S. officials failed to shift Washington’s position, despite efforts to de-escalate tensions.","European allies, including Germany and France, pledged military personnel to Greenland at Denmark’s request to bolster regional security.","Denmark criticized U.S. claims regarding Arctic threats, reaffirming its $15 billion investment in Arctic security over two years.","President Trump tied Greenland’s acquisition to U.S. missile defense and warned of Russian and Chinese interest in the territory."]

headline: Gaza Board of Peace launch
entry:
State of play: Trump wants to launch the Gaza Board of Peace this week at the World Economic Forum in Davos. He announced a new Palestinian technocratic government on Wednesday to oversee day-to-day governance in Gaza. It will be headed by Ali Shaath, a former deputy minister of transportation in the Palestinian Authority. Former UN envoy Nickolay Mladenov will serve as the Board of Peace "High Representative" for Gaza — effectively the CEO. Mladenov will report to an international Executive Board, which will include Trump's envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner; former U.K. Prime Minister Tony Blair; billionaire businessman Marc Rowan; the foreign minister of Turkey and ministers from Qatar and the UAE; Egypt's intelligence chief; Israeli-Cypriot billionaire Yakir Gabay; and former UN Gaza envoy Sigrid Kaag. "Each member of the Executive Board will be responsible for a defined portfolio critical to stabilizing Gaza, including governance capacity-building, regional relations, reconstruction, investment attraction, large-scale funding, and capital mobilization," the White House said. 

  

What they're saying: The Palestinian technocratic government released on Saturday its mission statement, which includes a commitment to peace. "We are committed to establishing security, restoring the essential services... as well as cultivating a society rooted in peace, democracy, and justice," the statement read. The new government also committed to "the highest standards of integrity and transparency." "We embrace peace, through which we strive to secure the path to true Palestinian rights and self-determination," the new government stressed. 

 

What to watch: Any hope of turning the Gaza truce into lasting peace depends on Hamas giving up its weapons, and on Israel pulling its troops back, rather than trying once again to disarm Hamas by force. 

 U.S. officials insisted in recent days that Hamas has privately signaled it's ready to accept the U.S. demilitarization plan and begin to disarm. They said the next 60 days will focus on getting this process going. "With the support of Egypt, Turkey, and Qatar, we will secure a COMPREHENSIVE Demilitarization Agreement with Hamas, including the surrender of ALL weapons, and the dismantling of EVERY tunnel," Trump said on Truth Social Thursday evening. He added: "Hamas must IMMEDIATELY honor its commitments, including the return of the final body to Israel, and proceed without delay to full Demilitarization. As I have said before, they can do this the easy way, or the hard way." 

 

The White House said Saturday that Army Gen. Jasper Jeffers will be commander of the International Stabilization Force in Gaza. Jeffers will oversee all security matters related to the Palestinian technocratic government, assist in efforts to demilitarize the Gaza Strip, and supervise the safe transfer of humanitarian aid and reconstruction materials to ensure they do not fall into Hamas' hands.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Hunger Is Spreading Rapidly Across Afghanistan (WFP/Afghanistan International/AFP, Jan 18)
entry:
The World Food Programme on Sunday warned of a sharp deterioration in Afghanistan’s hunger crisis, saying food insecurity and malnutrition are spreading across the country at an alarming pace. 

Earlier, John Aylieff, the WFP’s country director in Afghanistan, told Agence France-Presse that 2025 had already seen the highest surge in child malnutrition recorded in the country since the start of the 21st century. He said the number of malnourished children could rise to four million this year, a figure the agency has previously highlighted as a looming crisis. “These children will die if they’re not treated,” Aylieff warned. 

The WFP said it needs about $390 million over the next six months to provide food assistance to six million Afghans. Aylieff cautioned, however, that the prospects of securing the required funding are “very low” amid declining international support. 

 

According to WFP data, around five million mothers and children in Afghanistan are currently suffering from malnutrition. The country ranks fourth globally for acute child malnutrition. 

The agency has also warned that more than 17 million Afghans face severe food insecurity, particularly during the winter months, with the crisis compounded by widespread acute malnutrition. 

Figures show hunger is worsening compared with last year, with an additional three million Afghans at risk of acute hunger in 2026, underscoring what the WFP has described as one of the world’s most severe humanitarian emergencies.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: SAF and RSF clash on North Kordofan-Khartoum border (Sudan Tribune, 18 January)   Yale lab warns of imminent RSF siege on Sudan’s El Obeid (Sudan Tribune, 18 June)   Saudi gold refinery to buy Sudanese bullion as Khartoum shifts from Dubai (Sudan Tribune, 17 January)
entry:
Violent clashes broke out on Sunday between the SAF and RSF in border areas between North Kordofan and Khartoum states, involving various types of weaponry. Fighting in North Kordofan has intensified over several months as the RSF seeks to obstruct army advances from western Omdurman toward the state while attempting to secure El Obeid from the east. The paramilitary group is also working to prevent the army from moving out of El Obeid toward the south and west. Military sources told Sudan Tribune that a large RSF force launched a surprise attack on army positions along the Omdurman-Bara export road. Fierce fighting occurred in the Wadi al-Hout area, west of Rahid al-Nuba in the Jabrat al-Sheikh locality, where the army reportedly repelled the attack and inflicted heavy losses. Both sides utilized heavy artillery and drones during the engagement, according to sources. The RSF is pushing to control the entire export road to the outskirts of Omdurman. While the RSF currently holds the majority of the route, with a heavy presence in Jabrat al-Sheikh and Bara, the army controls sections extending from western Omdurman through Um Qirfa and Rahid al-Nuba. In a separate development, a spokesperson for the RSF-led Sudan Constituent Alliance accused armed groups allied with the army of attacking civilians in several Kordofan villages between January 15 and 17. The alliance claimed the attacks in villages, including Alouba, Um Qalib, Debiker, and Al-Adiya Qar’an, resulted in the deaths of 220 herders and the detention of many others. The spokesperson added that 912 people are currently reported missing following the violence. 

 

The Yale School of Public Health’s Humanitarian Research Lab (HRL) warned on Sunday of an imminent siege by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) on the city of El Obeid, as satellite imagery revealed significant defensive preparations and a mounting humanitarian crisis. While El Obeid faces a renewed threat of blockade, researchers reported that the cities of Kadugli and Dilling in the Nuba Mountains of South Kordofan are already under siege by an alliance between the RSF and the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement-North led by Abdelaziz al-Hilu. Analysts at the lab identified newly created earthen walls, or berms, along key exit points from the city and around critical infrastructure. This military activity is consistent with forces engaged in preparations for siege warfare, although the lab withheld specific locations due to human security risks. The report highlighted a trend likely to shape this phase of the conflict, characterized by an emphasis on aerial bombardment and the use of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) targeting civilian areas and vital facilities. Satellite imagery captured between January 2 and 14 corroborated damage to El Obeid’s power generation station consistent with bombardment. Open-source reports indicated that RSF drones struck the facility in the early hours of January 4, resulting in a shutdown of the electrical grid. The human toll has escalated in eastern El Obeid, where imagery from the same period confirmed damage to multiple buildings in the Al-Jallabiya neighbourhood. These findings align with local reports of RSF drone strikes on January 6 that allegedly killed at least 10 people, including eight members of a single family. The conflict has also triggered a surge in displacement. Researchers identified an increase of nearly 800 temporary structures at an internal displacement (IDP) camp in north-central El Obeid during the first half of January. These shelters included small blue tents, larger white tents, and white-toned tents with dark roof markings. Ground photographs have shown that many of these tents bear the insignia of Saudi Arabia’s King Salman Humanitarian Aid and Relief Centre. El Obeid remains a primary transit point for those fleeing violence further south, particularly as more people escape attacks in Dilling and Kadugli. Evidence of the rising death toll was visible at local cemeteries. Satellite imagery at the Zindi Cemetery showed approximately 60 new burial mounds and ongoing burial activity. At the Daleel Cemetery, analysts identified roughly 40 new burial mounds and observed people gathered around excavated holes in images from both January 2 and 14. The Kordofan region remains highly contested, with El Obeid currently under the control of the SAF but increasingly isolated by RSF positioning.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Myanmar Military Secures Enough Votes to Form New Government (The Irawaddy, 14 January)
entry:
Myanmar’s military-backed Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP) has already secured enough seats to form a government together with military appointees, ahead of the third and final phase of the junta-held election. The outcome marks the USDP’s pending return to power after its rigged election victory in 2010. The Union Election Commission (UEC) split the polls into three stages running from December 28 to January 25, citing instability. The vote has been widely condemned at home and abroad as a brazen bid to entrench rule by the generals five years after their 2021 coup. By the end of phase two, the USDP had amassed enough advance ballots alongside constitutionally reserved military seats to form a new government. A party needs to secure 50 percent of the reduced 588 seats in the national legislature in order to form a government. The USDP won 194 seats in the first two election phases. Combined with the military’s quota of 166 seats, the party now controls more than 360 seats—well above the 294-majority required to govern. The threshold was lowered after the junta called off elections in dozens of townships where it has lost control, cutting the Union Parliament from 664 members to 588. However, the military retained its quota and, with the USDP seats, has now achieved the threshold to entrench its rule. 

 

Results Under Fire 

In the first-phase vote held across 102 townships, the USDP won 124 seats—103 in the Lower House and 21 in the Upper House. Advance ballots reportedly accounted for 77 percent of the gains. Opposition complaints of a lack of transparency in advance voting were shrugged off by the junta-appointed Union Election Commission (UEC). The UEC has yet to announce the Phase Two results, but USDP officials said the party has won another 70 seats, bringing its total to 194. With the military’s 166 seat-quota, the bloc has secured a governing majority before a single vote is cast in Phase 3 on January 25. 

 

Overall Picture 

The ongoing election comes five years after the military scrapped the results of the 2020 vote, arrested President U Win Myint and State Counselor Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, and dissolved the elected National League for Democracy (NLD). With the NLD barred, the polls mark a USDP return after more than a decade of landslide NLD victories since the transition to civilian rule in 2012. The USDP last ruled in 2010 under General Thein Sein, after the NLD boycotted the election. The Thein Sein administration packed ministries with retired military officers while appointing ethnic Shan physician Dr. Sai Mauk Kham as a civilian figurehead in the role of vice president. Analysts forecast a return to “military ministers in civilian clothing” after Parliament convenes in March to appoint a new government expected by April. A path has also been cleared for coup leader Senior General Min Aung Hlaing to retain power in civilian clothing. The new president will be chosen from three vice presidents elected respectively by the Lower House, Upper House, and military appointees. Pro‑military media and USDP figures have already begun lobbying for Min Aung Hlaing, and the junta boss has not ruled out the possibility. Myanmar now sits poised for a return to military rule in civilian guise, as USDP veterans and regime loyalists prepare to take control of the country’s political future.
pu_note: PU Note: The announcement that the military-backed USDP has secured enough seats to form a government, even before the final phase of the election concludes on 25 January, stems from a highly controversial multi-phase voting process orchestrated by the junta's Union Election Commission (UEC). The polls, divided into three stages starting 28 December, were held amid widespread instability, with voting limited to select townships and canceled in others due to ongoing conflict. By the end of the second phase on January 11, the USDP claimed victories in approximately 87 out of 100 contested seats in that round, building on an earlier sweep of 88-90 seats in the first phase. Combined with the military’s constitutionally reserved 25% of parliamentary seats (166 out of 664 total in both houses), this gives the USDP and its allies a clear majority (potentially over 330 seats in the lower house alone) ensuring control over government formation.  This outcome echoes the USDP's rigged win in the 2010 election, marking a potential return to a quasi-civilian facade for military dominance five years after the 2021 coup that ousted Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD).

headline: United States will allow Mexico to continue shipping oil to Cuba (El País, 12 January)
entry:
Washington has not asked Mexico City to cut crude supplies to the island, Energy Secretary Chris Wright says. 

Donald Trump wants to bring countries across the Western Hemisphere under control like domino pieces on a geopolitical board. After Venezuela, he has turned his attention to Cuba. Warnings issued over the weekend by the Republican president, “Negotiate and reach agreements with the United States before it is too late,” have unsettled the island, which is struggling after the oil embargo imposed on Venezuela, its main source of fuel. Trump’s threats on the social network Truth have heightened anxiety in Havana. Cuba survived for many years thanks to Venezuelan oil and money. “THERE WILL BE NO MORE OIL OR MONEY FOR CUBA! ZERO!” the U.S. president wrote on Sunday. 

The Trump administration, however, does not appear willing to suffocate Cuba for now. The White House occupant’s statements seem more like a negotiating threat than a concrete warning. Energy Secretary Chris Wright has said that the United States has not asked Mexico to cut oil supplies to the island, according to CBS. Wright made the comment after cameras stopped rolling following an interview on Sunday on Face the Nation with journalist Margaret Brennan. 

Cuba depends on imported oil and fuel supplied mainly by Venezuela and Mexico to keep its power generators and vehicles running. Venezuela has been the main source of crude for Havana, exporting about 26,500 barrels per day last year, according to data compiled by Reuters. 

When Washington moved against Venezuela to oust President Nicolás Maduro, one of the conditions imposed on the new acting president, Delcy Rodríguez, was full control of the oil industry. The U.S. military maintains a blockade around the country and, in recent weeks, has intercepted five tankers attempting to evade sanctions. No oil leaves Venezuela without authorization from the Trump administration. To underscore the point, the president convened the world’s largest oil companies, most of them American, last Friday to divide up the Venezuelan crude market. 

As U.S. pressure on Venezuela has escalated and the military blockade has tightened since late September, Mexico has emerged as an alternative supplier for the island. Although the volumes are not yet significant, they are essential to preventing Cuba’s collapse. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum has described the oil as “humanitarian aid.” Mexico has been sending oil tankers to Cuba for several years. Since 2024, and following Hurricane Rafael’s passage over the island, shipments have been constant. Sheinbaum has acknowledged that while a large portion of the hydrocarbon cargoes are for humanitarian purposes, some are the result of contracts between Petróleos Mexicanos (Pemex) and the Cuban regime. Both the president and Pemex have avoided providing specific details on the shipments, their contents, or their cost. 

Sheinbaum has insisted that sending oil to the island is “legal” and part of the historic bilateral relationship with Havana. In recent weeks, at least three vessels have departed from the port of Coatzacoalcos, in Veracruz state, bound for Cuba, each carrying an estimated 80,000 barrels. “No more oil is being sent than has historically been sent,” the Mexican president has said. Pemex has reported to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that since July 2023 it has been shipping various hydrocarbons to the island through its subsidiary Gasolinas del Bienestar. In its latest filing, the state oil company estimated that under this model Mexico exported 17,200 barrels of crude per day in the first nine months of 2025, representing 3.3% of its total exports. 

The Mexican president held a phone call with Trump on Monday. After the exchange, Sheinbaum told the Mexican press that oil shipments to Cuba were not part of the conversation. She nevertheless suggested her willingness to act as “a channel of communication” between Havana and Washington. The Mexico–Cuba relationship, as well as the recent oil shipments, have also raised eyebrows among Republican lawmakers from the Cuban diaspora, who have accused Sheinbaum of “supporting the Cuban dictatorship” and being “its accomplice.” Some have even called on the Trump administration to condition the review of the USMCA free trade agreement, scheduled for July, on a complete halt to Mexican crude exports to the island.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Colombian rebels call for a ‘national accord’ after the U.S. intervention in Venezuela (AP News, 12 January)
entry:
Colombia’s largest remaining rebel group called on Monday for a “national accord” to overcome political conflicts in the South American nation, as it faces the prospect of attacks from both the Colombian and United States governments. 

In a statement published on its X account, the National Liberation Army (ELN) said that following elections in Colombia this year, it would like to work with the country’s new government to design agreements aimed at reducing poverty, protecting ecosystems, and “overcoming” the drug trade in rural areas. 

The statement comes amid reports that the governments of Colombia and the United States are exploring ways to conduct joint operations against the ELN, a group that Colombian President Gustavo Petro has described as “drug traffickers dressed up as guerrilla fighters.” 

Pressure on the ELN has increased since early January, when U.S. forces captured Venezuela’s former president Nicolás Maduro in a pre-dawn raid and transferred him to the United States to face drug trafficking charges. The indictment filed in New York accuses Maduro of providing protection to the ELN on Venezuelan territory and collaborating with the group to traffic cocaine. 

Since the raid, Colombian authorities have taken steps to weaken the ELN’s position in Venezuela. 

Last week, Colombian Interior Minister Armando Benedetti said that President Petro and U.S. President Donald Trump discussed the ELN and its role in drug trafficking during a phone call that helped ease tensions between the two leaders. 

According to Benedetti, the presidents talked about possible joint operations against the ELN. In an interview with Colombian radio station Blu, Benedetti said that “the issue with the ELN is that they need to be attacked when they retreat” into camps located in Venezuela. 

Petro said in a message posted on X on Monday that the ELN must give up drug trafficking and the recruitment of minors if it wants peace talks to resume. He also urged the group to stop using camps in Venezuela or face “joint actions” that would also involve Venezuela’s government. 

The Colombian government suspended peace talks with the ELN last year after the group launched an offensive in the northeastern Catatumbo region that forced more than 50,000 people to flee their homes. 

The ELN was founded in the 1960s by students and labor leaders inspired by the Cuban Revolution. It currently has an estimated 5,000 fighters operating in Colombia and Venezuela.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Nicaragua releases prisoners after U.S. demands, following Venezuela (Reuters, 10 Jan)
entry:
In a statement, the government of Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega announced the inmates' release without confirming the exact number of people freed or whether they had been detained for political reasons. Opposition leader and former prisoner Ana Margarita Vijil, head of the UNAMOS political movement, told Reuters that those released “are political prisoners, and several of them are our friends.”  

 

A human rights NGO that tracks political prisoners in Nicaragua identified 19 people released on Saturday. It's unclear whether those released will be restricted to house arrest. 

 

On Friday, the U.S. embassy in Nicaragua praised the release of opposition figures in Venezuela and called on Ortega's government to follow in their steps. "In Nicaragua, more than 60 people remain unjustly detained or missing, including pastors, religious workers, the sick, and the elderly. Peace is only possible with freedom!," the embassy tweeted. 

 

  

The move comes as Venezuela, also under U.S. pressure, begins releasing political prisoners. The development in Nicaragua reflects the degree of pressure that some left-wing governments in Latin America are under to appease U.S. demands, especially following last week's stunning capture of Maduro.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Boris Pistorius addresses Greenland sovereignty and NATO obligations
entry:
German Defense Minister Boris Pistorius expressed a calm outlook on the ongoing tensions surrounding Greenland, asserting that he does not anticipate escalation to extreme measures. US President Donald Trump has voiced intentions to assert control over Greenland, which Pistorius categorized as a power struggle to determine influence in the region. Pistorius emphasized the importance of securing Greenland from external influence, particularly given increased Russian and Chinese submarine activity.

He mentioned that while Trump’s administration has pursued this agenda, the broader US political landscape, including Congress and public opinion, might resist such efforts. Pistorius downplayed speculation on potential actions by Trump and underscored Germany's commitment to protecting NATO territories. He reiterated Germany's unwavering support for the sovereignty of Denmark and Greenland.

Addressing the Bundeswehr’s presence in Greenland, Pistorius stated it is coincidental in terms of timing and focused on fulfilling NATO obligations, including territorial security. He highlighted the increasing strategic significance of the Arctic, where Russia and China are expanding their military presence. The Bundeswehr's current activities aim to gather data and understand operational conditions in the region. Pistorius emphasized this preparedness underscores NATO’s collective security efforts and addresses any US security concerns related to the Arctic region.
author: Leon Henrik Thiel

headline: Trump speaks by phone with Delcy Rodríguez: “She’s a terrific person, we work very well with her” (El País, 14 January)
entry:
U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that he had spoken earlier that morning by phone with Venezuela’s acting president, Delcy Rodríguez, who has been in charge of the country since the abduction of Nicolás Maduro on January 3. The Republican’s surprise announcement comes one day before the Venezuelan opposition leader and Nobel Peace Prize laureate María Corina Machado is to be received in person at the White House. 

“We had an excellent conversation today, and she’s a terrific person,” Trump said of Rodríguez, without mentioning her by name, to reporters gathered in the Oval Office. “In fact, we’ve worked very well with her. Marco Rubio is in touch with her. I spoke with her this morning. We had a call, a long call, we talked about many things, and I think we’re getting along very well with Venezuela.” 

The U.S. president was responding to a question from a reporter who appeared to be asking about Venezuelan Interior Minister Diosdado Cabello, whose name also did not come up during the exchange. “He doesn’t seem very willing to cooperate,” the reporter said. “I don’t know who that number two is, I know the number one,” Trump replied, referring to Delcy Rodríguez. He also boasted about the good state of relations between Washington and Caracas. “They just gave us 50 million barrels [of oil] a day,” he added, as evidence. 

Following Trump’s remarks, Rodríguez posted a tweet confirming a “long and courteous telephone conversation” with the U.S. president, “conducted within a framework of mutual respect.” “We addressed a bilateral work agenda for the benefit of our peoples, as well as pending issues between our governments,” wrote the Chavista leader, without offering further details about the call or those “pending issues.” 

Earlier in the day, Rodríguez had appeared before reporters in Caracas for the first time since Maduro’s arrest. It was a statement without questions. In a brief declaration, she said that “Venezuela is opening itself to a new political moment that allows for understanding from divergence and from political and ideological diversity.” 

The acting president also reported on the release of detainees, which she said had benefited 406 people. She sought to dissociate those releases from U.S. intervention, stating that they had begun last December and had been ordered by Maduro himself. 

“In December 2025, a process of releasing people deprived of liberty was initiated in order to open spaces for understanding, for coexistence, for tolerance,” Rodríguez said from the Miraflores Palace. “That process remains open and is precisely what we have been coordinating with the justice system in Venezuela.” 

At that time, Rodríguez did not mention any call with Trump, but she did refer to a meeting with her brother, parliamentary speaker Jorge Rodríguez, and Interior Minister Diosdado Cabello. The three senior Chavista figures appeared together before the cameras, evidence that all three remain in charge, after Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, were captured and taken to New York 11 days earlier. 

The call with Maduro’s trusted confidant and the imminent meeting with the Venezuelan opposition leader clearly illustrate the dual strategy Trump is pursuing. Just hours after Maduro’s capture, Trump said he did not see Machado as ready to lead Venezuela. 

Machado is due at the White House on Thursday to try to assert her suitability as an interlocutor in the United States’ plan to oversee Venezuela and take charge of its oil. She will also seek to clarify what role the Venezuelan opposition will ultimately be assigned, in light of Trump’s initial bet on Rodríguez.
author: Gregoria Verity

European allies have responded by signaling concrete military support for Denmark. Germany and France stated they would send military personnel to Greenland, while Sweden and Norway separately announced similar deployments (14 Jan 2026, Reuters). Germany confirmed that a 13-member reconnaissance team would deploy from Thursday to Saturday to assess conditions and explore potential military contributions to support Denmark in ensuring regional security, including possible maritime surveillance roles (14 Jan 2026, Reuters). The German government emphasized that the mission was undertaken at Denmark’s request and in coordination with other European partners. 
These European deployments reflect growing concern within Europe about the implications of U.S. rhetoric and the stability of transatlantic relations. President Trump has repeatedly asserted that Greenland is strategically vital to U.S. security and has stated that all options remain on the table to secure the territory, language that European officials say has severely strained relations between the United States and its allies (14 Jan 2026, Reuters). Denmark and Greenland, while seeking continued dialogue, have publicly reinforced that sovereignty is non-negotiable and that security concerns should be addressed through alliance cooperation rather than territorial acquisition (14 Jan 2026, Politico). 

  • Trump Pursues Greenland Amid "Fundamental Disagreement" with Denmark and Greenland (NYT/Politico/The Hill, Jan 14) 

 

President Trump continues his campaign to acquire Greenland despite unified rejection from Danish and Greenlandic officials, who met with top US administration officials Wednesday to address what Denmark's Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen called a "fundamental disagreement" over the Arctic territory's future. 

 

Greenland's significance extends far beyond territorial ambitions. The island is losing ice rapidly as the Arctic warms at least twice as fast as the rest of the planet due to fossil fuel emissions. In the 12 months ending August 31, 2025, Greenland lost 105 billion metric tons of ice, contributing to global sea-level rise that has increased by four inches since 1993. 

 

Climate change is opening new Arctic shipping routes, particularly China's "Polar Silk Road" through Russia's northern coast, and providing access to critical minerals including graphite, zinc, and rare earths essential for renewable energy technologies. "His fixation on Greenland is an admission that climate change is real," said John Conger, a former Pentagon official now advising the Center for Climate and Security. 

 

Diplomatic Tensions and Local Opposition 

The meeting between Rasmussen, Greenland Foreign Minister Vivian Motzfeldt, Vice President JD Vance, and Secretary of State Marco Rubio marked the first senior-level engagement since Trump revived his territorial ambitions. The parties agreed to establish a working group, expected to meet within weeks, to address American security concerns while respecting Denmark's territorial integrity and Greenland's self-determination. 

"The discussions focused on how to ensure the long-term security in Greenland, and here our perspectives continue to differ," Rasmussen stated, emphasizing it is "absolutely not necessary" for the US to own Greenland. 

 

Trump's aggressive rhetoric has backfired locally. Nearly a dozen Greenlanders interviewed in Nuuk expressed growing resentment toward his approach. "We cannot be bought. That is not something we want to be a part of," said Nuuk Mayor Avaaraq S. Olsen. The Greenland Dog Sledding Association revoked an invitation to Trump's Greenland envoy after the president's dismissive joke about Denmark's contribution being "one more dogsled." 

 

Trump's Strategy and Regional Realities 

According to sources familiar with Trump's thinking, his preferred strategy involves incentivizing a referendum for Greenland to align with the US through information campaigns and financial inducements. However, Trump's public statements—including that owning Greenland is important for "psychological" reasons and refusing to rule out military force—have hardened opposition. A 2025 poll showed 85% of Greenlanders opposed leaving Denmark to align with the US. 

 

Greenland Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen declared: "If we have to choose between the United States and Denmark here and now, we choose Denmark. We choose NATO. We choose the Kingdom of Denmark." 

Rasmussen challenged Trump's security narrative, noting that according to Danish intelligence, no Chinese warship has been in Greenland for roughly a decade. Independent researchers support this assessment, with Arctic Institute senior fellow Gabriella Gricius calling claims about Russian and Chinese ships circling the island "just not true." 

 

Denmark announced increased military presence around Greenland, with Swedish and other European soldiers arriving at Denmark's request. Meanwhile, bipartisan US lawmakers have expressed opposition to any use of military force against the NATO ally, with Senator Rand Paul calling Trump's approach counterproductive despite agreeing on Greenland's strategic importance.

headline: Putin's Strategic Silence: Russia's Calculated Response to US Global Actions (ISW/GZero, Jan 16)
entry:
Vladimir Putin's geopolitical worldview was shaped by a pivotal 1989 phone call. As protesters approached the KGB villa in Dresden during the Berlin Wall's collapse, Putin requested Soviet reinforcements. "Moscow is silent," came the reply. The Kremlin's refusal to deploy troops—a "paralysis of power"—allowed the Soviet empire to crumble, leaving Putin humiliated and enraged. 

Putin has spent his career overcoming this humiliation. Yet over the past year, as allies have been ousted or bombed—often by the US—Putin has been curiously silent himself. 

 

A Pattern of Restraint 

Russia's reactions to recent US actions reveal calculated restraint. When the US conducted military operations in Venezuela on January 2-3, 2026—including airstrikes and seizing Nicolás Maduro—Moscow's response was notably muted. The Foreign Ministry issued routine condemnations, while Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov expressed support for Venezuela's new president, Delcy Rodríguez. UN Representative Vasily Nebenzya used standard anti-Western rhetoric about "neocolonialism and imperialism." 

Security Council Chairman Dmitry Medvedev provided inflammatory commentary—accusing Trump of violating international law while praising him for protecting US interests—fulfilling his typical role of making extreme statements to shift the Overton Window. Significantly, Putin and official Kremlin spokespersons remained completely silent. 

 

Precedents and Constraints 

This pattern mirrors Russia's response to US-Israeli strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities in June 2025. Moscow issued boilerplate condemnations but provided no material support. Similarly, when jihadist militias overthrew Kremlin-backed Syrian strongman Bashar al-Assad, Russia offered only rhetorical outrage. 

Russia's hands are full with Ukraine. Putin's invasion, entering its fifth year, represents Moscow's deadliest and costliest conflict since World War II, draining manpower, attention, and resources. Unlike the Soviet bloc maintained for four decades, today's Russian alliances with Iran, Syria, and Venezuela are looser and more opportunistic. 

While Putin suffers immense pressure to preserve control over Ukraine—a core interest—there's less reason risking direct conflict with the US or important partners like Israel and Arab states over more distant allies. Washington remains the key player in Ukraine negotiations where Putin hopes Trump will endorse his maximalist territorial and demilitarization demands.
