headline: Gaza   Board of Peace   World leaders show caution on Trump's broader 'Board of Peace' amid fears for UN   On the ground, Israel continued its violations of the Gaza ceasefire on Sunday morning.
entry:
• Local media reports also said that Israeli forces carried out air raids, demolished homes and targeted refugee camps. In the eastern areas of Gaza City, Israeli forces flattened residential buildings using explosives, while military vehicles opened fire towards the al-Tuffah neighbourhood and Jabalia. 

  • Hamas intends to hand over responsibilities for the enclave to the Gaza administration committee. The group sent a message to mediators, demanding that the first phase of the truce is fully implemented before the issue of disarmament commences under the second phase. A leading source in Hamas said the group had urged in a meeting held in Cairo last week that Israel fulfils the terms of the first phase of the deal, noting that the Rafah crossing had not been opened, nor have prefabricated homes been allowed in or equipment to remove rubble. The group also noted that hundreds of Palestinians have been killed since the ceasefire came into effect. 

  • Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) is prepared to cooperate with the Gaza administration committee, despite reservations about the newly formed peace council, spokesman Mohammed al-Hajj Musa said on Sunday. Speaking to The New Arab’s Arabic language sister publication, Al-Araby al-Jadeed, the PIJ spokesperson said his group is keen on working alongside Ali Shaath, the head of the administration committee, to alleviate the suffering of civilians in Gaza. He said the main reservations about US President Donald Trump's "Board of Peace" are that its formation and membership serve Israeli interests. 

  • Trump invites 60 nations to join 'Board of Peace'; Permanent membership available for states that pay $1 bln; Board to start work on Gaza and expand to other conflicts; Trump to be chairman for life 

  • Governments reacted cautiously on Sunday to U.S. President Donald Trump's invitation to join his "Board of Peace" initiative aimed at resolving conflicts globally, a plan that diplomats said could harm the work of the United Nations.  

  • Only Hungary, whose leader is a close Trump ally, gave an unequivocal acceptance in response to the invitations, which have been addressed to some 60 nations and began arriving in European capitals on Saturday, according to diplomats. 

  • Other governments appeared reluctant to make public statements, leaving officials to express concerns anonymously about the impact on the work of the U.N.(January 18, Reuters and the new Arab) 

The board would be chaired for life by Trump and would start by addressing the Gaza conflict and then be expanded to deal with other conflicts, according to a copy of the letter and draft charter seen by Reuters. Member states would be limited to three-year terms unless they pay $1 billion each to fund the board's activities and earn permanent membership, the letter states. "This simply offers permanent membership to partner countries who demonstrate deep commitment to peace, security, and prosperity," the White House said in a post on X. 

 

  • Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, visiting South Korea, told reporters her country was "ready to do our part", although it was not clear whether she was specifically referring to Gaza or the broader peace. 

  • Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney said on Sunday he had agreed to Trump's Board of Peace for Gaza in principle although details were still being worked out. 

 

A mandate for a Board of Peace was authorized by the United Nations Security Council in November, but only through 2027 and solely focused on the Gaza conflict. Russia and China, two veto wielding powers, abstained, complaining that the resolution did not give the U.N. a clear role in the future of Gaza. 

 

The inclusion of a 'charter' in the invitation letter stoked concerns among some European governments that it could undermine the work of the United Nations, which Trump has accused of not supporting his efforts to end conflicts around the world. "It's a 'Trump United Nations' that ignores the fundamentals of the U.N. charter," said one diplomat. Three other Western diplomats said it looked as if it would undermine the United Nations if it went ahead. A further three diplomats and an Israeli source said that Trump wanted the Board of Peace to eventually have a broader role beyond Gaza that would oversee the other conflicts that Trump has said he has resolved. 

 

  • The leaders of France, Germany, Italy, Hungary, Australia, Canada, Pakistan, the European Commission and key Middle East powers were among those invited, according to officials. "We have, of course, accepted this honourable invitation," Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban, a close ally of Trump, wrote on X. 

 

The document said "durable peace requires pragmatic judgment, common-sense solutions, and the courage to depart from approaches and institutions that have too often failed". There was a "need for a more nimble and effective international peace-building body", it added. 

  

A spokesperson for U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said Guterres "believes Member States are free to associate in different groups" in response to a question about the draft U.S. charter for a Board of Peace. "The United Nations will continue with its mandated work," deputy U.N. spokesperson Farhan Haq said. Trump, who covets the Nobel Peace Prize, said in the letter that the board would convene in the near future, adding: "This board will be one of a kind, there has never been anything like it!" 

Another senior U.N. official did not address the plan directly, but said the United Nations was the only institution with the moral and legal ability to bring together every nation, big or small. "And if we question that ... we fall back and very, very, dark, times," Annalena Baerbock, president of the United Nations General Assembly, told Sky News, adding that it was up to individual states to decide what to do. 

Trump has long been wary of multilateral institutions, particularly the United Nations. He has repeatedly questioned the effectiveness, cost and accountability of international bodies, arguing they often fail to serve U.S. interests. The U.S., which is required to pay 22% of the U.N.'s regular budget, currently owes $1.5 billion, according to U.N. officials. 

 

The White House on Friday named some individuals who will sit on the board, which would outlive its role supervising the temporary governance of Gaza, under a fragile ceasefire since October. 

They included U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio, President Donald Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff, former British prime minister Tony Blair and Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner.Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas signed off on Trump's plan, which says a Palestinian technocratic administration will be overseen by an international board, which will supervise Gaza's governance for a transitional period. 

 

TRUMP GOES FOR GLOBAL PEACE ROLE 

"It's going to, in my opinion, start with Gaza and then do conflicts as they arise," President Donald Trump told Reuters in an interview earlier this week. Many rights experts and advocates have said that Trump overseeing a board to supervise a foreign territory's governance resembles a colonial structure, while Blair's involvement was criticized last year due to his role in the Iraq war and the history of British imperialism in the Middle East.The White House did not detail the responsibilities of each member of the board. The names do not include any Palestinians. The White House said more members will be announced over the coming weeks. It also named a separate, 11-member "Gaza Executive Board" to support the technocratic body including officials from Turkey and Qatar. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said the composition of this board had not been coordinated with Israel and contradicted its policy.
pu_note:
Netanyahu released an unusually pointed statement objecting to the "executive board" for Gaza, which the White House named on Friday. The committee, which reports to the Trump-led Board of Peace, includes the foreign minister of Turkey and a senior Qatari official, despite Netanyahu's insistence that those countries have no role in governing Gaza. The announcement stunned Netanyahu, who was not consulted. The Israeli media quickly started reporting on the idea that Qatar and Turkey — key mediators on the Gaza deal who both have fractious relationships with Israel — would be wielding influence. "The announcement... was not coordinated with Israel and runs counter to its policy. The Prime Minister instructed the Foreign Minister to raise this matter with the U.S. Secretary of State," Netanyahu said. 

 

The other side: Asked by Axios about Netanyahu's comment, the senior U.S. official doubled down. 

 The official said Netanyahu was not consulted on the membership of the committee because he does not have a say in the matter. "If he wants us to deal with Gaza, it will have to be our way. We worked over him. Let him focus on Iran and let us deal with Gaza. We are not going to argue with him. He will do his politics and we will keep moving forward with our plan. He can't really go against us," the U.S. official said. The senior official added that unless Netanyahu wants to send Israeli troops back into the fight in Gaza, with the U.S. withdrawing from this issue, he'll have to get with the U.S. program. "We are doing him a favor. If this fails he can say, 'I told you so.' We know that if it succeeds he will claim credit." 

 

Between the lines: While Trump personally has kept up a close relationship with Netanyahu, many on his team are fed up with the Israeli prime minister's hardline stances in Gaza and beyond. They're also worried that if they can't build momentum behind phase two of the deal, Israel will resume the war. 

The U.S. official claimed that while Netanyahu is highly skeptical the U.S. plan would work, he likes its content. The official said that "nobody in Israel believed we will get this far - but we managed to do it."

headline: Russia welcomes Trump's tariffs on NATO allies over Greenland as 'collapse' of alliance (Kyiv Independent, Jan18)
entry:
Russian officials enthusiastically welcomed President Donald Trump's threat to impose tariffs on NATO allies over Greenland, portraying the move as evidence of Western alliance collapse. Kremlin economic negotiator Kirill Dmitriev declared on January 17 that the tariffs signal the "transatlantic alliance is over," mocking European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and warning European leaders against "provoking" Trump. 

 

Tariff Details and Context 

Trump announced 10% tariffs on eight NATO allies—France, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Germany, the UK, the Netherlands, and Finland—effective February 1, escalating to 25% by June 1. The tariffs remain until Washington reaches a deal to purchase Greenland, which Trump has vowed to acquire "one way or the other." The announcement came days after European forces from France, Germany, and other nations began military exercises in Greenland. 

 

Medvedev's Provocative Response 

Former President Dmitry Medvedev, known for inflammatory rhetoric, framed Trump's threats as proof of deepening NATO divisions. He claimed the US is "preparing to attack Greenland, choosing the island itself rather than some kind of Atlantic solidarity," while European countries face punishment "with tariffs" for depending on American protection. Medvedev has previously mocked Western unity and encouraged Trump to quickly annex Greenland, reflecting Moscow's strategic interest in exploiting US-allied rifts. 

 

Strategic Significance 

Greenland, population 56,000, hosts a US military base and holds growing strategic importance amid intensifying Arctic competition. Trump claims US control would make NATO "more formidable and effective," though European leaders reject this assertion. 

 

Several EU countries have publicly supported Denmark since Trump renewed threats, signaling alarm over NATO cohesion. Cyprus, holding the EU's rotating presidency, announced EU ambassadors will convene an emergency meeting January 18 to assess the situation and coordinate responses. 

Moscow's enthusiastic reaction underscores Russia's strategic calculation that transatlantic divisions serve its interests, particularly regarding Ukraine negotiations and broader geopolitical positioning against Western unity.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: FM Lavrov on Venezuela, US tariff threats on Russia's partners, Macron's policy (TASS, Jan 14)
entry:
Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov delivered extensive statements on Russia's diplomatic position regarding US relations, the Venezuelan crisis, and Ukrainian settlement prospects. His remarks emphasized Moscow's openness to dialogue while criticizing Washington's international conduct. 

 

Russia-US Contacts and Ukraine 

Lavrov characterized President Putin's meetings with American emissaries Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner as "serious, specific, aimed at understanding the root causes of the Ukrainian crisis and agreeing on ways to overcome these root causes." Moscow remains open to further contacts with the envoys and expressed interest in hearing their impressions from meetings with the European "coalition of the willing." 

Significantly, Lavrov noted that Washington wants to stop attempts to "draw Ukraine into NATO," which Moscow has "taken note of." Putin has repeatedly confirmed Russia's openness to negotiations if they are of a "serious nature." 

 

However, Lavrov dismissed European proposals for a ceasefire before settlement as attempts to buy time for Kyiv and preserve the regime. He characterized French President Macron's stated intention to contact Putin as "playing to the gallery, microphone diplomacy, megaphone diplomacy, which has never led to anything good." Lavrov asserted the collective West is preparing for war with Russia, claiming "they openly talk about it." 

 

Criticism of US International Conduct 

Lavrov sharply criticized Washington's global behavior, stating the US has violated the international relations system it helped create decades ago. He accused America of flushing the globalization system "down the drain," arguing that rejection of its own globalization principles "makes our American colleagues look unreliable." 

The foreign minister suggested Washington's "unscrupulous methods of foreign trade policy" indicate "the competitive position of the United States is gradually deteriorating." He called America's proposed 500% duties on countries doing business with Russia "laughable," urging Moscow to focus on implementing existing partnership agreements. 

 

Venezuela Crisis 

Lavrov condemned the US operation in Venezuela as illegal, an assessment he claimed is "shared by the vast majority of the world's nations." Moscow remains "committed to the agreements that have been reached" with Caracas and is watching "with great interest, concern and sympathy" how Venezuelan leadership defends national interests. 

He noted Venezuela's readiness for dialogue with the US if based on "equality, mutual respect and rejection of unilateral methods of dictate," though he found it difficult to predict outcomes as Venezuela defends "its national sovereignty and its place in international relations" as an equal, independent state. 

 

On Iran, Lavrov stated no third party can change Russia-Iran relations, as they "meet the interests of two states, two peoples."

headline: In Guinea-Bissau, the junta amends the constitution and establishes a presidential regime - A month and a half after the coup, the legislative body of
entry:
From now on, it is the presidential regime that prevails in Guinea-Bissau. A month and a half after deposing President Umaro Sissoco Embaló in a bizarre coup on 26 November and suspending the ongoing electoral process, the ruling military led by General Horta N'Tam has amended the constitution. The National Transitional Council (NTC), the legislative body whose 65 members were appointed by the junta, voted unanimously on Tuesday to amend the constitution, moving the country from a semi-parliamentary to a presidential regime. The new text, the final version of which AFP has not obtained, is to be promulgated by the head of the junta and published in the official gazette. 

 

The president will appoint the prime minister 

In this new version of the Constitution, the president appoints the prime minister and members of the government and can dissolve parliament. The National People's Congress also changed its name and was now called the National Assembly. Until now, the Prime Minister came from the majority in Parliament, which has led to difficult cohabitations as was the case after the 2023 legislative elections. President Embaló dissolved the opposition-dominated parliament in December 2023, following what he described as an attempted coup. He ruled by decree until his dismissal on November 26. 

 

"The NTC is not legally legitimate" 

"If the law is enacted and published, it will put an end to the two-headed system at the top of the state. In recent years, we have experienced crises between the President of the Republic and his Prime Minister, who is leaving the party that won the legislative elections," said Mamadu Queita, a member of the NTC as a representative of civil society. 

However, the legal validity of this constitutional amendment raises questions. "We are living in a very dangerous and unpredictable situation. Because this National Transitional Council is not legally legitimate. So any decision that emanates from such an institution has no legal value," said Toni Checka, a political commentator interviewed by a Portuguese radio station. "What is the military high command (the junta's governing body) looking for, if not to concentrate all power in the hands of a single man who is the absolute leader," worries Nex Farias, a doctoral student in law.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Bukele arrives in Costa Rica to sponsor a high-security prison inspired by his mega-prison for gang members (El País, 14 January)
entry:
El Salvador’s president, the populist Nayib Bukele, arrived in Costa Rica on Tuesday for an official visit during which he will lay the cornerstone of a high-security prison inspired by the model he himself implemented in El Salvador to combat gangs. The visit has sparked controversy because it takes place in the middle of Costa Rica’s electoral campaign. Costa Rica’s Supreme Electoral Tribunal has warned the Salvadoran president that he may not interfere in the country’s internal political debate. 

Bukele landed at Base 2 of Costa Rica’s Ministry of Public Security, located at Juan Santamaría Airport, where he was received by Costa Rican Vice President Mary Munive and Foreign Minister Arnoldo André. The controversial visit is taking place amid Costa Rica’s political campaign ahead of the February 1 elections, in which the ruling party’s candidate, Laura Fernández, is leading in the polls. 

On Monday, Costa Rica’s Supreme Electoral Tribunal (TSE) rejected an appeal filed by a citizen seeking to block Bukele’s visit, but warned that the president may not intervene in domestic affairs. “The taking of a position by a foreign head of state — in favor of or against any of the political options competing — would constitute a violation of Public International Law,” the tribunal stressed. 

Bukele is scheduled on Wednesday to lay the first stone of the Organized Crime High Containment Center (CACCO), a project inspired by the Terrorism Confinement Center (CECOT), El Salvador’s mega-prison for gang members and a symbol of Bukele’s government’s “war” against these groups. The future Costa Rican prison, which will cost 35 million dollars, will have five modules with a total capacity of 5,100 inmates and, according to the government, will be used to hold the most violent prisoners. 

The project comes at a time when Costa Rica is registering historic homicide figures: around 900 per year, of which authorities attribute 70% to drug trafficking. Last December, Costa Rican President Rodrigo Chaves visited El Salvador, where he met with Bukele and toured the CECOT. 

Bukele had already visited Costa Rica on November 12, 2024, and toured the country’s main prison, known as La Reforma. There, he warned that he perceived certain “symptoms” of criminality in the country similar to those he had faced in El Salvador with gangs. 

On September 24, during an official event inaugurating port scanners, Costa Rica’s Presidential Office released a video in which Bukele delivered a message in favor of the “continuity” of projects of the Chaves government. The message was later used by the ruling party’s candidate, Laura Fernández, in her campaign. “If the next administration gives continuity to the projects of this government, I have no doubt that Costa Rica’s best days are ahead, a safer and more prosperous Costa Rica,” Bukele said in that video.

headline: The Israeli army carried out multiple incursions in southern Lebanon overnight from Saturday to Sunday, demolishing houses and business, while announcing the completion of a “two-month” mission aimed at fighting Hezbollah presence.
entry:
• Hezbollah Secretary-General Sheikh Naim Qassem escalated his rhetoric on Saturday against those advocating for the state’s monopoly on weapons, describing calls for the party’s total disarmament as an “Israeli-American demand.” 

  • The leader harshly denounced “groups under American tutelage who encourage Israeli aggression,” singling out Foreign Minister Joe Rajji of the Lebanese Forces. Qassem accused Rajji of being “aligned with the Israeli position” and of seeking to “drag Lebanon into civil war.” 

Around 11 p.m. Saturday, troops entered the town of Odaisseh in the Marjayoun district, where they blew up a house and a blacksmith’s workshop used daily by a local craftsman, according to our regional correspondent. Around midnight, another Israeli troop infiltrated Kfar Kila, also in the Marjayoun district, and demolished a building, near which the Lebanese Army had established a fixed outpost in the town's old square. Meanwhile Israeli artillery shelled the outskirts of Kfar Shuba in the Hasbaya district. 

  

On Sunday, the Israeli army released a statement on X saying: "Our troops have concluded a two-month mission in southern Lebanon to prevent Hezbollah from taking root. They collected intelligence, located enemy infrastructure and supported ground and air forces to dismantle Hezbollah terrorist sites and neutralize its operatives," accompanied by videos of strikes on targets presented as Hezbollah members and equipment. According to the local channel LBCI, the statement refers to "the multidimensional unit operating under the command of the 91st Division to prevent Hezbollah from establishing a presence in the area." Since the cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah on Nov. 24, 2024, the Israeli army has carried out near-daily violations, from bombings to incursions in southern Lebanon, in addition to troops continued occupation of several Lebanese positions. 

  

Meanwhile since September of last year, the Lebanese Army has begun efforts to disarm Hezbollah, which has voiced resistance of relinquishing its weapons. Hezbollah Secretary-General Sheikh Naim Qassem escalated his rhetoric on Saturday against those advocating for the state’s monopoly on weapons, describing calls for the party’s total disarmament as an “Israeli-American demand.”  

 “If we are not all united, no one will survive,” he said. The leader harshly denounced “groups under American tutelage who encourage Israeli aggression,” singling out Foreign Minister Joe Rajji of the Lebanese Forces. Qassem accused Rajji of being “aligned with the Israeli position” and of seeking to “drag Lebanon into civil war.” “Undermining Lebanon’s stability and the resistance, as an essential component of the country, will affect everyone. Not a stone will be left, and no one will be spared,” Qassem said, in a barely veiled threat. “If this resistance, this social base, and these people are not preserved, and if we are not all united, no one will survive,” he added.
pu_note:
Qassem responded by saying the government “bears responsibility for addressing this anomaly called the ‘foreign minister,’” whom he accused of failing to represent Lebanon’s position. He called for Rajji’s removal, silence, or alignment with what he described as the national stance. “One of the reasons for the government’s poor performance is the absence of a foreign minister who voices Lebanon’s demands,” he said.The Hezbollah leader also argued that Israel “has no connection” to UN Security Council Resolution 1701, which calls for the disarmament of militias in Lebanon and forms the basis of the ceasefire that took effect in November 2024. He described the resolution as “a purely Lebanese matter,” alongside issues such as arms monopoly and national defense strategy. 

  

'Israeli-American demand' 

Qassem said the government decision last August to enforce a state monopoly on weapons amounted to an “Israeli-American demand aimed at encircling the resistance,” rather than a Lebanese choice. 

 “If we do not have weapons and do not defend ourselves, who guarantees that Israel will not violate every inch of Lebanese soil?” he asked. “The resistance will remain, and Lebanon will not be without resistance,” he insisted. He also urged the Lebanese state to secure the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanese territory, where Israel still controls at least five points near the border. “After the cease-fire agreement, the state became responsible for protecting the country and its people, after decades of neglect,” he said. Finally, Qassem addressed the uprising in Iran over the past three weeks, saying its aim was to “bring down the Iran of the resistance.” Echoing Iran’s Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei, he accused U.S. President Donald Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of activating “agents.” “We stand with Iran and believe it is steadfast and strong. God willing, it will remain a stronghold of jihad and resistance,” he said

headline: Ukraine’s new defense minister reveals scale of desertions as millions avoid the draft (AP, Jan 14)
entry:
Wide-scale desertions and 2 million draft-dodgers are among a raft of challenges facing Ukraine’s military as Russia presses on with its invasion of its neighbor after almost four years of fighting, the new defense minister said Wednesday. 

Mykhailo Fedorov told Ukraine’s parliament that other problems facing Ukraine’s armed forces include excessive bureaucracy, a Soviet-style approach to management, and disruptions in the supply of equipment to troops along the about 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line. 

He said the military had faced some 200,000 troop desertions and draft-dodging by around 2 million people. 

 

President Volodymyr Zelenskyy appointed 34-year-old Fedorov at the start of the year. The former head of Ukraine’s digital transformation policies is credited with spearheading the army’s drone technology and introducing several successful e-government platforms. 

His appointment was part of a broad government reshuffle that the Ukrainian leader said aimed to sharpen the focus on security, defense development and diplomacy amid a new U.S.-led push to find a peace settlement. 

 

The European Union will dedicate most of a massive new loan program to help fund Ukraine’s military and economy over the next two years, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said Wednesday. 

EU Unveils €90 Billion Loan Package for Ukraine as US Aid Dries Up (The Guardian/Politico/Kyiv Independent, Jan 14)  

The European Commission announced a comprehensive €90 billion ($105 billion) loan package for Ukraine on Wednesday, designed to prevent financial collapse as the war approaches its fifth year and American aid evaporates under President Donald Trump. The proposal represents Europe's largest financial commitment to Kyiv since Russia's full-scale invasion. 

 

Loan Structure and Distribution 

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen outlined that €60 billion ($70 billion) will fund military spending, with the remaining €30 billion ($35 billion) supporting Ukraine's general budget operations. The package covers approximately two-thirds of Ukraine's needs for 2026-2027, calculated at €52 billion for budgetary support and €83 billion for defense during this period. 

The Commission aims for initial cash disbursements in April, when Ukraine's war chest runs out. The proposal must first receive approval from EU member states and the European Parliament, with lawmakers potentially fast-tracking the measure as early as next week. Treasury and defense officials are scheduled to meet Friday to expedite the process. 

 

Repayment Terms and Russian Assets 

Ukraine will only repay the loan if Russia pays post-war reparations—an unlikely scenario. If this doesn't materialize, the EU has left open the possibility of tapping approximately €210 billion in frozen Russian state assets held within the bloc, primarily in Belgium's Brussels-based financial depository Euroclear. 

Von der Leyen emphasized that using Russian assets "remained on the table," stating: "We reserve the right to make use of the Russian immobilized assets." Economy Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis added that "the Union reserves its right to use the cash balances from immobilized Russian assets held in the EU to repay the Ukraine Support Loan." 

 

While interest-free for Ukraine, the loan will cost EU taxpayers between €3-4 billion annually in borrowing costs from 2028. The EU can indefinitely roll over debt by issuing eurobonds until finding necessary repayment means.

headline: Melting ice may raise Greenland’s value. Trump’s fight may be just the start (Washington Post, Jan 18)
entry:
The Arctic is warming approximately four times faster than the global average, fundamentally transforming the region's strategic significance. This environmental shift is exposing natural resources, opening potential shipping routes, and intensifying military activity among global powers—factors directly influencing President Donald Trump's pursuit of Greenland, despite his dismissal of climate change as a "hoax." 

 

 

Trump cites Greenland's strategic location and untapped resources, including diamonds, lithium, and copper, as motivations for acquisition. Sherri Goodman, former deputy undersecretary of defense for environmental security, notes that melting sea ice makes the territory increasingly attractive for economic development Trump would pursue. Trump announced Saturday tariffs on countries deploying troops to Greenland, while this week's talks between Greenland, Denmark, and US officials ended in "fundamental disagreement," according to Danish Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen. 

 

Emerging Shipping Routes 

Arctic sea ice typically peaks in March before melting to minimum extent by September. Over five decades, changing ice cover has revealed commercial pathways: the northern sea route along Russia's coast and the northwest passage along northern Canada. Icebreakers now traverse a "central route" over the Arctic's top. In October, a Chinese container ship used the northern route, cutting approximately 20 days from its typical Suez Canal journey to Europe. 

A 2021 Nature study found that at 2°C (3.6°F) warming above 1850-1900 averages, open-water periods lengthen by 63 days. At 3.5°C (6.3°F) warming, nearly the entire Arctic would experience at least three months of annual open water—potentially reshaping global trade within decades. 

 

 

Underestimated Hazards 

Scientists warn the melting Arctic presents significant risks despite perceived opportunities. The region will remain extreme regardless of ice-free summers. Sea ice loss removes crucial protection against erosion and flooding, particularly when fall typhoons bring massive Pacific swells. Melting could produce unpredictable ocean conditions—wind and wave changes—while few accessible ports exist for emergencies. Climate scientist Zack Labe suggests conditions "could become more hazardous for ships rather than less." 

 

Strategic Implications 

Trump's Greenland pursuit coincides with cutting funding for climate initiatives including Arctic research. Goodman warns this represents poor geopolitical strategy: "Climate change is a significant national security risk. The openings of sea lanes, the changing ice conditions, are contributing to the intense geopolitical situations we're experiencing." Trump's bid exemplifies how climate change increasingly influences international relations and territorial ambitions.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Domestic reaction, opposition leaders (Reuters, 6 Jan)
entry:
Domestic reaction, opposition leader Machado vows to return (Reuters/ El Pais 6 Jan, UNOCC, Grok Sentiment Analysis) 

 

Venezuela's acting President Delcy Rodriguez on Tuesday declared seven days of mourning for members of the military killed in the U.S. raid over the weekend to capture leader Nicolas Maduro. Venezuela’s Attorney General is cited announcing the appointment of three prosecutors to investigate civilian and military casualties resulting from the 3 January US strikes on the country. 

 

Pro-government women rallied in Caracas today to demand the release of President Maduro and his wife. Yesterday, Maduro supporters gathered peacefully at US embassies in Honduras and Guatemala to protest US actions in Venezuela. 

The ruling United Socialist Party of Venezuela (PSUV) and loyalists have condemned the U.S. action as an illegal invasion, kidnapping, and violation of sovereignty. 

According to UN sources, Venezuelan opposition figure Henrique Capriles, affiliated with Primero Justicia party, has called for a peaceful, constitutional resolution to the crisis in Venezuela, saying on X that"El momento es ahora" (The moment is now), framing the current crisis as an opportunity for responsible change while criticizing past failures under the regime He urged an end to abuses of power and failed negotiations, the release of political prisoners, the return of exiles, urgent economic measures and a unified, internationally supported transition to restore democracy, stability and economic recovery.  

Capriles has not directly mentioned Maduro's capture, the U.S. operation, or Delcy Rodríguez's interim role in his recent X posts. He avoids explicit celebration or condemnation of the U.S. action. His welcome of democratic progess contrasts with the more jubilant tone from Machado/Gonzalez. There is visible criticism of Henrique Capriles on X from within opposition circles (or anti-regime users) in recent days (since January 3-7, 2026). These critics often accuse him of being too conciliatory (e.g., favoring dialogue, negotiation, and avoiding confrontation), compromising with the regime (historical references to past elections or dialogues), or outright betraying the opposition cause by not fully endorsing the U.S. action against Maduro. 

In a television interview on Monday, opposition notable María Corina Machado stated her intent to return to Venezuela “as soon as possible” and declaring her movement ready to win a free election. She praised President Trump for toppling enemy Maduro, even though she had not spoken with US President Trump since October 2025.   

Edmundo González Urrutia, the candidate who challenged Maduro at the polls on July 28, 2024, has been exiled in Spain for over a year. In Venezuela, most opposition officials have been sidelined for months by government repression, operating in hiding or in prison. All demand security guarantees for a return home, a task they entrust to the United States. If the opposition leadership's first reaction was their willingness to immediately replace Chavista officials, the reality check imposed by the Republican president's choice of Delcy Rodríguez ended up redefining their strategy. The priority is no longer assuming power, but returning to Venezuela. The return represents not only a minimum condition to begin a change of cycle, even under White House oversight, but an urgent political necessity for the exiled opposition. 

Andrés Velásquez of the Causa R party, an opposition-aligned minor party published a communiqué on social media supporting Venezuelans’ push for democracy and condemning Maduro’s prior disregard of the popular vote and ongoing repression. The group demanded the release of all political prisoners and warned that a true transition required dismantling the regime’s means of control.  

Trump, however, has said the U.S. needs to help address Venezuela's problems before an election, calling a 30-day timeline unrealistic. "We have to fix the country first ... There’s no way the people could even vote," Trump told NBC. The Trump administration has put hardline Interior Minister Diosdado Cabello on notice that he could be at the top of its target list unless he helps Rodriguez meet U.S. demands and keep order, according to three people familiar with the matter. 

Cabello, who controls security forces accused of widespread human rights abuses, is one of a handful of Maduro loyalists that Trump has decided to rely on as temporary rulers to maintain stability during a transition period, said one source briefed on the administration’s thinking. Cabello has been on the streets of Venezuela, patrolling with security forces.
pu_note:
PU Note: The domestic reactions appear highly polarized and emotionally charged. Rodríguez calling for national mourning reinforces the government's narrative that Venezuela suffered an illegitimate act of war by the U.S. and projects institutional control, likely continue rallying and encourage loyalists around national grievance. 

 

While the opposition and leaders are likely to continue gaining support from Trump, he has, however, been told by the CIA that Rodriguez and other senior officials from Maduro's government are the best bet to maintain stability, sources said. The classified assessment was one reason why Trump decided to back Rodriguez instead of opposition leader Machado, the sources said. Trump appears to be encouraging Maduro loyalists to collaborate with Rodríguez, potentially trying to contain internal cohesion and reaction after the outcry from capturing Maduro instead of signaling support for Trump-aligned Venezuelan opposition. His approach suggests a preference for stability through regime insiders, not the opposition, which strengthens conditions to enact the oil partnerships he is seeking. 

 

This creates mixed messages to Venezuelans: the U.S. removed Maduro but is not yet supporting a clear opposition-led transition. Rodríguez's position is stronger than it looks—because the U.S. is treating her as an operational partner. Her reassertion of institutional control, indicates chavista structures remain operational despite Maduro's capture.

headline: Canadian PM Carney’s visit to China (DPPA, 01/16)
entry:
Canadian PM Mark Carney arrived in Beijing on 14 January for a state visit and met with President Xi. According to Beijing’s readout, President Xi and PM Carney portrayed bilateral ties as entering a “turnaround” and a “new trajectory of positive development”, signaling a thaw after recent strains.  

President Xi said the two sides have already reached “positive outcomes” on resuming cooperation across sectors and called for advancing a new strategic partnership, marked by sound, steady, and sustainable development. He urged both countries to lengthen the list of cooperation while shortening the list of irritants.  

 

PM Carney echoed the forward-looking tone, citing extensive common interests, strong economic complementarity, and a desire for a strong and enduring partnership. The meeting concluded with a joint leaders’ statement, underscoring momentum toward normalization. The joint statement included pledges to: (i) restart the high-level China-Canada Economic and Financial Strategic Dialogue; (ii) implement a Canada-China Trade Cooperation Roadmap; (iii) strengthen energy and law enforcement cooperation; and (iv) establish a financial working group. PM Carney also met with Premier Li Qiang, whose message was that the two countries are at a “new starting point” and stressed the importance of deepening cooperation to protect multilateralism and trade.  

 

Background: Diplomatic relations between China and Canada ruptured in 2018, when China arbitrarily detained two Canadian citizens after Canada arrested a Chinese business executive wanted in the US. The fallout included high retaliatory tariffs on key exports, including Chinese EVs along with Canadian canola oil and other agricultural goods.
pu_note:
Carney is the first Canadian prime minister to visit China since 2017. 

Carney's trip comes amid Ottawa's efforts to diversify trade amid tariffs from the US. 

China, also hit by US tariffs, has been strengthening ties with the Group of Seven (G7) nations — traditionally in the sphere of US influence. 

China has been strengthening its exports in markets other than the US. Beijing has been banking on trade to drive the economy amid a prolonged property slump and sluggish demand at home.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: OAS Special Meeting
entry:
• OAS holds special meeting on Venezuela, members urged to return to accepted norms and principles. 

 

Organization of American States (OAS) held a special meeting on Venezuela at which the OAS Secretary General urged members to act collectively to return to accepted norms and principles of democracy, fundamental principles of international law and the inter-American legal framework: “OAS Charter and the inter-American legal framework are not a suggestion, but an obligation and a moral responsibility...This is not only a Venezuelan issue. It is a hemispheric responsibility. The stability of our region depends on our collective response.” 

 

The OAS Secretary General outlined specific mechanisms through which the Organization stands ready to support Venezuela and Member States. These include: 

 

  1. 1. Support an IACHR In Loco Visit: The SG “strongly supports” the request of the Inter‑American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) to conduct an in loco visit to Venezuela to assess the human‑rights situation. 

  1. Good Offices & Inclusive Dialogue Platform “facilitate an inclusive dialogue platform among the actors of Venezuelan society.” 

  1. This platform would help identify priorities, assess needs, and define a shared roadmap. 

  1. Provide Legal, Institutional & Anti‑Corruption Support. The OAS has “the capabilities and proven experience to reinforce the independence of the judiciary and the rule of law through: 

  1. Advisory services and technical cooperation to reinforce the independence of the judiciary. 

  1. Strengthening rule of law, including access to public information and integrity frameworks. 

  1. Supporting anti‑corruption standards. 

  1. Tools for preventing, managing, and peacefully resolving social and political conflicts, including mediation, dialogue facilitation, consensus‑building, and peacebuilding methodologies. 

  1. Provide Independent Technical Support for Electoral Integrity and credibility of electoral processes. 

  1. This includes assistance to electoral authorities to foster public confidence in democratic outcomes. 

  1. Human Rights Monitoring & Public Denunciation of Abuses, with particular attention to political prisoners, and will publicly denounce abuses consistent with Inter‑American Human Rights System commitments. 

  1. Migration‑Related Support (with partners) In collaboration with regional and international specialized agencies, the OAS can contribute to:  

  1. Addressing migration‑related challenges, 

  1. Supporting groups in situations of vulnerability, 

  1. Promoting social cohesion and democratic resilience.

headline: Chavismo accelerates the release of prisoners amid expectations and doubts (El País, 12 January)   Trump to meet Venezuelan opposition leader Machado
entry:
Differences between the reported numbers of released detainees stem from the complexity of a process involving judges, prosecutors, and prison authorities. 

After several days of piecemeal releases, the Venezuelan government announced on Monday that it has freed 116 prisoners, a gesture through which chavismo seeks to send a message of openness. The figures, however, remain confusing. Human rights organizations have so far only been able to confirm the release of 49 people, including 24 freed during the early hours of Monday and the remainder who have been released since last Thursday, when the government announced the liberation of “a significant number” of detainees. According to sources familiar with the process, the discrepancy between the figures is explained by the complexity of the procedures that must be coordinated among judges, prosecutors, and prison authorities before a release is carried out. 

This first official figure would represent the most significant act of clemency in a Venezuela without Nicolás Maduro, a process that still generates many doubts among humanitarian organizations but also a degree of optimism. According to a source involved in the negotiations, this is a historic moment in the release of prisoners in Venezuela. The country’s prisons still hold between 800 and 1,000 political prisoners, according to organizations that monitor their highly contested judicial proceedings. 

Negotiations to secure their release are taking place on multiple fronts, with each country exerting its own pressure. These are complex talks, and although several mediators attribute to Delcy Rodríguez, the acting president, a willingness to cooperate, she herself faces internal resistance. “There are disagreements within the regime,” says a diplomatic source who has maintained dialogue with Caracas for years. “Some do not want to give ground, while Delcy Rodríguez does,” the source adds. “She has always been in favor of this process,” says another interlocutor about the leader, who, on the other hand, has overseen the Bolivarian Intelligence Service (SEBIN), an agency responsible for a large share of arbitrary detentions. 

Negotiations over the release of political prisoners have been a constant over the past decade, but the capture of Nicolás Maduro by U.S. special forces on January 3 has opened a new and unpredictable scenario. Contrary to many forecasts, chavismo has remained standing, and Delcy Rodríguez has assumed control of the country, backed by President Donald Trump. Several interlocutors in contact with Caracas who spoke to El País in recent days attribute to the new president a greater willingness to loosen the hardline approach that characterized madurismo, while acknowledging internal resistance within the core of power. 

The main declared objective of the United States, after removing Maduro and his wife Cilia from the country, is for U.S. companies to be able to exploit Venezuelan oil. But Washington, judging by the words of Trump and his associates, is also exerting pressure for the regime to show signs of openness, through measures such as the release of prisoners. In this context, National Assembly president Jorge Rodríguez announced last Thursday the release of “a significant number” of detainees, without specifying figures, presenting it as “a unilateral gesture to strengthen peace.” He also thanked Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, former Spanish Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, and Qatar for their mediation, a message aimed at distancing the process from Washington’s shadow. 

The announcement raised expectations among the nearly 1,000 families with relatives imprisoned for political reasons. Although the confirmed figures remain modest, Trump celebrated last Saturday: “Venezuela has started the process, in a big way, of freeing its political prisoners. Thank you! I hope those prisoners remember how lucky they were that the U.S. came in and did what had to be done,” he wrote on his social network. If they do not, he warned, “it will not be good for them.” 

The releases are proceeding slowly and in stages. At Christmas and New Year, the government announced similar measures for another 187 detainees that never fully materialized. The legal procedure remains unclear: courts should issue release orders and prison directors should immediately open the gates, but in several cases detainees do not leave even with those documents in hand. The opacity surrounding the figures and the gap between official announcements and reality has become a constant of chavismo in moments of high political pressure. Meanwhile, arbitrary detentions have not ceased. 

Alfredo Romero, director of Foro Penal, is skeptical. In his view, this process “resembles previous ones that have occurred since 2016” and does not represent structural change. “These are negotiations to make gestures to public opinion. In each process, they never release the number they announce, because they include people who are not political prisoners; that is why they do not give names, only numbers,” he says. “Always, after each process, new people are jailed, cells are emptied and then filled again. And the repressive system continues and is not dismantled.”  

In recent years, especially during 2025, releases have focused on foreign nationals as part of negotiations with the United States and other countries. Foro Penal describes many of these cases as “foreign hostages”: people who are not activists or political prisoners but whom the government uses as diplomatic bargaining chips, as occurred in previous exchanges linked to Alex Saab or to the nephews of Maduro and Cilia Flores, who were handed over by Washington in various negotiations in exchange for U.S. citizens h

headline: How Many People Has Trump Deported So Far? (NYT, Jan 17)
entry:
President Trump's administration deported approximately 500,000 people in his first year back in office, according to New York Times analysis of federal data. This includes 230,000 people arrested inside the country and 270,000 at the border. An additional 40,000 people "self-deported" through a novel administration program offering stipends, bringing the total to 540,000. 

However, total deportations remain lower than Biden's final two years (590,000 in 2023, 650,000 in 2024), when border crossings reached record highs. Southwest border crossings have since fallen to record lows. 

 

 

 

Counting Methodology 

Deportation counting lacks straightforward legal definition. The figures include removals by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), responsible for interior enforcement, and Customs and Border Protection (CBP), responsible for borders and entry points. Some cases involve both agencies. 

Of the total, CBP directly deported or denied entry to 120,000 people, while ICE deported approximately 150,000 arrested at the border—14% of whom were already in detention before Trump took office. Border deportations still comprise about half the total despite increased interior enforcement. 

Homeland Security claimed over 622,000 deportations in December but provided no detailed breakdown. The department's statistics division has published no routine reports since Trump took office. 

 

Enforcement Visibility 

Immigration arrests have become dramatically more visible and community-disruptive under Trump. The administration aggressively publicizes enforcement through slickly produced videos, memes, and mugshots. 

"At-large" arrests—apprehensions on streets, in courthouses, homes, and businesses—quadrupled to approximately 150,000, now constituting the majority of immigration arrests in 32 states and Washington, D.C. These arrests were most common in California, Illinois, and New York, where local governments block jails from transferring people to ICE custody. Previously, ICE made most arrests quietly through partnerships with local jails and prisons. 

 

Deportation Demographics 

Monthly deportation rates increased for most countries worldwide while actually falling for some Central American nations. Deportations of people with violent criminal convictions doubled, while deportations of those with no criminal record increased more than sixfold. 

Other significant increases include people residing in the U.S. four or more years (from 1,300 to 3,500 monthly), potential "Dreamers" who entered before age 16 (from 170 to 470 monthly), and children (from 10 to 60 monthly). Deportations of people with pending criminal charges rose from 750 to 2,700 monthly. 

The shift partly reflects Trump's revocation of temporary legal status for millions who entered legally under Biden policies. These individuals face deportation unless they leave voluntarily. 

 

Population Impact 

Experts agree Trump's policies have begun shrinking the undocumented population but dispute the magnitude. The population without legal status or with only temporary protection reached an estimated 14 million in 2024. 

Homeland Security claims over 2.5 million people left due to the crackdown, though immigration experts dispute this figure. The Congressional Budget Office reports the undocumented population decreased by approximately 360,000 in 2025, while the overall foreign-born population increased by 400,000. Another study estimated the total foreign-born population decreased between 10,000 and 295,000 in 2025.

headline: South Sudan army deploys reinforcements to Jonglei after rebel advance (Sudans Post, 18 January)
entry: South Sudan’s military deployed reinforcements to the volatile Jonglei State late on Saturday to protect the state capital Bor, a security source said, following a rebel advance that saw opposition forces overrun a strategic town earlier on Friday. The convoy of troops, armored vehicles, and logistics trucks departed the capital Juba on Saturday evening. The deployment is primarily defensive and aimed at stabilizing the security perimeter around Bor rather than launching an immediate counter-offensive against the Sudan People’s Liberation Army in Opposition (SPLA-IO), a senior security source told Sudans Post. “The reinforcement is not for an offensive operation,” said the source, who requested anonymity due to the sensitivity of the operation. “The priority is to defend Bor and stabilize the situation. At the same time, a much larger force is being prepared to eventually clear the entire state of rebel presence.” Witnesses in Gumbo Shirkat, a neighborhood on the eastern outskirts of Juba along the main highway, described a heavy military presence moving north. Residents reported a mix of troop carriers and armored vehicles, noting the scale of the movement was “unusual for a Saturday night.” “We saw many military trucks moving fast toward Bor,” one resident said. “This was not a normal movement.” The urgent deployment follows the capture of Pajut by SPLA-IO forces on Friday morning. The town lies along the main arterial route north of Bor and holds significant strategic value for controlling movement across central Jonglei. Its fall has raised alarm in Juba that opposition forces could utilize the position to push further south toward the state capital. The rebels captured approximately two dozen war captives during the takeover of Pajut. Among those detained were police officers and senior army officers, including personnel holding the rank of brigadier general. The South Sudan People’s Defence Forces (SSPDF) have not officially confirmed the loss of the town or commented on the reported capture of its personnel and equipment. Separately, military officials confirmed that Lt. Gen. Johnson Olony Thabo, the deputy chief of defence forces for mobilisation and a prominent former rebel commander, was present in neighboring Lakes State on Friday as the security situation in Jonglei deteriorated. High-level security commanders are expected to travel to Bor in the coming days to assess the situation on the ground. The source indicated that the military leadership is launching an inquiry into the circumstances under which government forces withdrew from Pajut. “There will be an assessment on the ground — what happened, why positions collapsed and how to prevent further advances,” the source said. The escalation underscores fears of a return to civil war, which ended in September 2018 with the signing of the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (R-ARCSS). Control of the strategic town of Bor shifted repeatedly during the five-year conflict. The latest clashes highlight the fragility of the security arrangements and the risk of a return to full-scale hostilities between government forces and the opposition, both signatories to the peace deal. Analysts attribute the rising tensions to the detention and ongoing trial of First Vice President Riek Machar. The opposition leader was arrested in March 2025 and has since been suspended from office pending the court’s verdict.

Recent developments, including SPLA-IO’s 72-hour evacuation ultimatum for civilians and aid workers in Bor and Duk, underscore the immediate threat of urban fighting. With over 180,000 already displaced and at least four health facilities looted, the humanitarian situation is critical. The 2018 Peace Agreement (R-ARCSS) is increasingly viewed as defunct by SPLM-IO forces due to the continued detention of First Vice President Riek Machar. Possible scenarios include a large-scale government counter-offensive to prevent a siege of Bor, which risks sparking full-scale hostilities across Jonglei and Upper Nile states.

headline: US Pushes Ahead With Plans to Reopen Embassy in Venezuela (Bloomberg, 8 Jan)
entry:
The Trump administration is quickly moving to reestablish a diplomatic presence in Venezuela, asking local staff to prepare for the arrival of US officials at its embassy in Caracas as soon as this week. When asked about the possibility of reopening the embassy by reporters aboard Air Force One Sunday, President Donald Trump said, “we’re thinking about it.” A senior State Department official said that they are making preparations to allow for a reopening should Trump make that decision. 

 

The timing underscores how rapidly Washington is seeking to reset relations after Delcy Rodríguez was sworn in as acting president on Monday.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: María Corina Machado Fights to Avoid Being Sidelined in a Possible Transition in Venezuela (El Pais, 12 Jan)
entry:
María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s leading opposition figure and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, is scheduled to hold a personal meeting this week with U.S. President Donald Trump, the White House has confirmed. The meeting aims to close the gap created by a paradoxical cooling of relations between the two.  

 

After Maduro’s arrest, Trump announced a negotiated “transition” with the interim president, Delcy Rodríguez, explicitly ruling out Machado as the right person to govern under current conditions. In this way, Trump sidelined the opposition movement with the strongest internal and external Venezuelan support from a transition whose terms remain undefined—and, crucially, without territorial or institutional control at this stage.The White House has effectively moved past the results of Venezuela’s disputed 2024 presidential election, which numerous international reports said was won by Edmundo González Urrutia, Machado’s endorsed candidate, after she was barred from running. 

 

While Machado enjoys enormous popular support, she lacks deep backing within the Bolivarian Armed Forces, which continue to underpin the regime. In addition, the government maintains a broad territorial network of armed civilian groups—the so-called colectivos—that could jeopardize stability during any abrupt transfer of power. 

 

However, Machado declared herself ready to assume power. She has insisted that the Chavista government is weak, internally divided, and entering a “decisive phase.” 

 

Machado remains determined to maintain Washington’s favor, embracing pragmatism despite the contradictions of recent days. She envisions Venezuela as a future strategic ally of the United States and has therefore avoided openly criticizing Trump’s decisions on oil and natural resources, though she has expressed reservations about a transition led by Delcy Rodríguez. She has even offered to Trump her Nobel Peace Prize, though the Norweigan Peace Institute has said it cannot be “transferred to others.”
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Ukrainian Intelligence Claims Chechen Leader Was Hospitalized, Creating Risk of Destabilizing Succession (FDD, Jan 14)
entry:
hechen President Ramzan Kadyrov has been hospitalized due to kidney failure and is reportedly undergoing dialysis, according to a report sourced from Ukraine’s Defense Intelligence. While not publicly confirmed, the report follows others that the 49-year-old strongman’s health has been declining in recent weeks and that Moscow is searching for a successor. 

 

On January 5, Ramzan Kadyrov appointed his eldest son, 20-year-old Akhmat, as acting deputy prime minister. That’s a rapid promotion from minister of sports and physical culture and suggests Ramzan is preparing to hand off power. Any succession between strongmen is fraught with instability and this one is a risk for both the Kadyrovs and Moscow. 

 

Years of Questions Over Kadyrov’s Health 

Novaya Gazeta Europe reported that Ramzan Kadyrov’s health deteriorated sharply after he arrived in Moscow on December 24 for a State Council meeting with Russian President Putin, requiring him to be rushed to the hospital. 

Speculation about Kadyrov’s health has grown since 2019, fueled by public absences and fluctuations in his weight. In a 2024 report, Novaya Gazeta claimed that he had been diagnosed with pancreatic necrosis in 2019. Chechen authorities have tried to quash such reports but have not released medical information about Kadyrov. 

 

The Kadyrovs Are a Deadly Dynasty 

Russia fought two vicious wars and a lingering Islamist insurgency in Chechnya in the decade following the Soviet Union’s dissolution. Memories of the brutality on both sides remain vivid. Moscow finally brought Chechnya to heel by devastating it — and by co-opting elements of the insurgency under Ramzan Kadyrov’s father, Akhmat. 

In return for his personal fealty to Putin, Kadyrov receives outsized federal subsidies and the leeway to run Chechnya as his personal fiefdom. His rule has been marked by severe human rights abuses, including extra-judicial killings, which have led to deep but largely suppressed grievances. Kadyrov concentrates power and money in a narrow patronage network comprised of relatives and cronies, keeping a lid on rivalries between factions. 

 

Both of Kadyrov’s Sons Are too Young To Take Power 

In recent years, Kadyrov has taken steps aimed at ensuring his dynastic regime. Still, his appointment of his eldest son came as a surprise. Attention had focused on his third son, 18-year-old Adam, who has taken on several official positions over the last two years, including acting as his father’s head of security. 

 

Media reports indicate officials in the Kremlin and the Federal Security Service (FSB) favor alternative candidates, notably Apti Alaudinov, commander of the “Akhmat” unit, and Adam Delimkhanov, one of Kadyrov’s closest allies. And assuming the minimum age requirement for the job remains in place, a placeholder would be needed if Ramzan dies or leaves office before either son reaches 30. 

 

For the Kremlin, the nightmare scenario is a breakdown in control that leads to a renewed insurgency. It would undermine Putin’s origin story as the man who stopped the Russian Federation’s disintegration and brought Chechnya back into the fold. It could also divert resources from other priorities, such as Russia’s war in Ukraine. Ultimately, the succession will likely be arbitrated in Moscow, hinging on the preferences of the security services and Kremlin approval as much as on local clan dynamics. 

 

A Potential Time Bomb for Russia That May Present an Opportunity to the West 

U.S. and Western intelligence agencies should closely monitor developments in Chechnya with an eye toward taking advantage of scenarios ranging from a smooth transfer of power to a Putin- or Kadyrov-backed successor to a prolonged and violent power struggle. If the latter occurs before the war in Ukraine ends, internal Russian chaos may create opportunities for Ukraine to exploit.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: With Milei present and Lula absent,  Mercosur and EU sign historic trade agreement in Asunción after 26 years of negotiations (MercoPress, 19 January)
entry:
The European Union and South America’s Mercosur bloc signed their long-negotiated association and free trade agreement on Saturday in Paraguay, with Argentina’s President Javier Milei attending the ceremony and Brazil’s Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva absent, represented instead by his foreign minister. 

The signing ceremony took place at the Gran Teatro José Asunción Flores, the same venue where the founding treaty of Mercosur was signed in 1991. Under the format agreed for the event, the treaty was formally signed by Mercosur foreign ministers and the EU’s trade commissioner, Maroš Šefčovič. 

Milei called the deal “the most important achievement in Mercosur’s history” and said Argentina would continue to pursue additional trade initiatives beyond the EU agreement, according to Argentine coverage. 

EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen praised Lula’s commitment to “values important to us, such as democracy, the international rules-based order and respect for communities and sovereign nations,” while European Council President António Costa said the agreement affects more than 700 million people across both regions. 

Paraguay’s President Santiago Peña, hosting the summit as Mercosur’s rotating chair, argued that Europe and South America should “unite” in a “complex, unstable” world, as reported by local outlets. 

The agreement aims to phase out tariffs on more than 90% of bilateral trade and would create one of the world’s largest integrated free trade areas, with a combined market of roughly 720 million people. EU–Mercosur trade reached about €111 billion in 2024, with EU exports focused on machinery, chemicals and other industrial goods, while Mercosur exports are dominated by agricultural products and minerals. 

Lula’s absence became a focal political detail. AFP reported—citing a presidency source—that the Brazilian president would not travel to Paraguay for the signing, even as he publicly defended the agreement’s economic potential. 

Ratification remains uncertain. The deal still needs approval by the European Parliament and by the legislatures of Mercosur’s full members—Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay. European farmers and environmental groups have raised concerns about increased South American imports and environmental impacts, including deforestation. 

On the EU side, the Council adopted decisions authorising the signature of the comprehensive partnership agreement and an Interim Trade Agreement, designed to advance the commercial pillar as the broader treaty proceeds through political steps. 

Regional reporting in South America highlighted that implementation details—technical standards, sectoral safeguards and domestic adjustment measures—will be shaped during the ratification phase and subsequent regulatory work in each member state. 

AP described the signing as taking place amid heightened global trade tensions, with the EU seeking to strengthen its strategic and economic footprint in South America. EFE likewise presented the agreement as the culmination of 26 years of negotiations, with the process still facing political hurdles and internal debates—particularly in Europe—before it can take effect.
author: Gregoria Verity
ai_summary: ["The EU and Mercosur signed a landmark free trade agreement, creating a combined market of 720 million people.","The agreement plans to eliminate tariffs on over 90% of bilateral trade, but ratification faces political and environmental hurdles.","Argentina’s President Milei hailed the deal as Mercosur’s greatest achievement, while Brazil’s Lula was absent, represented by his foreign minister.","EU leadership emphasized shared values like democracy and international order, positioning the deal as critical amid global trade tensions.","Implementation and technical details will be finalized during ratification, with opposition from EU farmers and environmental groups remaining significant."]

headline: US President Donald Trump decided last week not to strike Iran after consultations with regional leaders and assessments that US/allied readiness and likely consequences made an immediate attack unwise,  (18 Jan 2026, Israel Hayom).
entry:
• Several Iranian state TV channels were hacked, airing anti-regime messages and protest footage (18 Jan 2026, Israel Hayom). 

    ·       The United States reinforced its regional posture, with the Abraham Lincoln at the Strait of Malacca and two destroyers in company, plus 12 F-15s arriving in Jordan, as officials said ‘all options are on the table’ should Trump decide to strike Iran (18 Jan 2026, Jerusalem Post). 

    ·       A brief, heavily filtered internet restoration in Iran was reported after a 10-day blackout, as protests—sparked by economic grievances and met with a deadly crackdown—continued to draw international attention; President Masoud Pezeshkian warned an attack on the Supreme Leader would mean full-scale war (18 Jan 2026, Al Monitor; New Arab). 

    ·       An Iranian official said at least 5,000 people were killed in recent unrest, the judiciary hinted executions may proceed, and HRANA reported 3,308 confirmed deaths and over 24,000 arrests, while Khamenei acknowledged ‘several thousand’ deaths (18 Jan 2026, New Arab). 

    • Netanyahu asked Trump to delay a potential strike as Israel assessed readiness and the speed of Washington’s shift, with reporting that deaths spiked on Jan 8–9 and protests surged to around one million people before subsiding under repression (18 Jan 2026, Jerusalem Post). 

    Reporting indicates that Washington refrained from an immediate strike on Iran following consultations with regional leaders and intelligence assessments emphasizing limited operational readiness and the risk of unfavorable consequences within the available window (18 Jan 2026, Israel Hayom). In lieu of a rapid attack, the United States has shifted to a strategy of building options, including expanded military planning and preparations for new sanctions targeting regime-linked officials and companies (18 Jan 2026, Israel Hayom). This recalibration places emphasis on gaining leverage while avoiding near‑term escalation, even as pressure on Tehran intensifies (18 Jan 2026, Israel Hayom). 

    Concurrently, the US military posture in and around the Middle East has been reinforced, with the USS Abraham Lincoln and its escorts transiting the Strait of Malacca toward CENTCOM’s area and additional fighter aircraft deploying to the region, including 12 F‑15s to Jordan, to provide the White House with a wide range of options(18 Jan 2026, Jerusalem Post; 18 Jan 2026, Israel Hayom). US officials framed the buildup with the statement that ‘all options are on the table’, a formulation intended to keep credible military pressure while political decisions are weighed (18 Jan 2026, Jerusalem Post). Israeli leadership engaged intensively in consultations, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu convening senior ministers to review developments (18 Jan 2026, Jerusalem Post). 

    Inside Iran, the information environment has been highly constrained by a 10‑day nationwide internet blackout (18 Jan 2026, Al Monitor; New Arab). A monitor noted only a brief, filtered restoration before services dropped again (18 Jan 2026, Al Monitor). Against this backdrop, several state television channels were hacked to broadcast anti‑regime messages and protest footage, providing a rare breach of official narratives (18 Jan 2026, Israel Hayom). The state media breach and intermittent connectivity underscore a contested communications space at a time of acute domestic unrest (18 Jan 2026, Israel Hayom; 18 Jan 2026, Al Monitor; New Arab). 

    Casualty reporting remains contested but points to extraordinary levels of violence. One Iranian official cited at least 5,000 killed, including security personnel, while HRANA reported 3,308 confirmed deaths with thousands more under review and over 24,000 arrests, and Khamenei himself acknowledged ‘several thousand’ deaths (18 Jan 2026, New Arab). The judiciary signaled that some detainees could face the capital charge of ‘moharebeh’ and warned that those deemed responsible for violence would ‘not be spared’ (18 Jan 2026, New Arab). These statements suggest a continuation of harsh punitive measures even as authorities claim calm has been restored (18 Jan 2026, Al Monitor; New Arab). 

    In the regional and political arena, President Masoud Pezeshkian warned that an attack on the Supreme Leader would constitute full‑scale war (18 Jan 2026, Al Monitor; New Arab). Commentary cited by Israeli media discussed the possibility that a ‘dramatic’ one‑time strike could target the Supreme Leader, though analysts cautioned that such an action might not produce regime change and could empower security hardliners (18 Jan 2026, Jerusalem Post). The Israeli prime minister’s reported request for a delay was linked to questions of Israeli air defense and allied readiness, as well as uncertainty about the strategic efficacy of an immediate operation (18 Jan 2026, Jerusalem Post). 

    Chronologically, the most intense violence in the streets appears to have occurred around 8–9 January, with reports that deaths surged to the thousands and protester numbers spiked sharply before the crackdown reduced visible mobilization (18 Jan 2026, Jerusalem Post; 18 Jan 2026, Al Monitor; New Arab). Since then, the state has used security deployments, arrests, and the information blackout to reassert control, while the United States moved additional assets into theater to reopen a military option that had been judged imprudent in the immediate term (18 Jan 2026, Israel Hayom; Jerusalem
author: Gregoria Verity
