headline: Trump signs executive order meant to protect the money from Venezuelan oil (AP, 10 Jan)
entry:
The executive order, made public on Saturday, says that if the funds were to be seized for judicial proceedings, it could “undermine critical U.S. efforts to ensure economic and political stability in Venezuela.” It also says that oil revenue is property of Venezuela that is being held by the United States for “governmental and diplomatic purposes” and not subject to private claims. Its legal underpinnings are the National Emergencies Act and the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.   

 

The order comes amid caution from top oil company executives that the tumult and instability in Venezuela could make the country less attractive for private investment and rebuilding. The CEO of ExxonMobil, the largest U.S. oil company, said that the commercial constructs and frameworks in place today in Venezuela today are “uninvestable”. In response, Trump said Sunday that he is “inclined” to keep ExxonMobil out of Venezuela, potentially inhibiting them from oil revenue.  

 

On Friday, Trump called on oil executives to rush back into Venezuela as the White House tries to quickly secure $100 billion in investments to fix the country’s neglected infrastructure and fully tap into its expansive reserves of petroleum. Trump used the meeting to publicly assure executives that they need not be skeptical.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Managua releases political prisoners as Trump’s democratization drive has far-left rulers on their toes (MercoPress, 12 January)
entry:
The Sandinista regime of Daniel Ortega and Rosario Murillo announced on Saturday that Managua would release a series of political prisoners in a gesture marking the 19th anniversary of the far-left administration, without acknowledging that the move could also amount to a concession to Washington, as the Donald Trump government embarked on a campaign to rid the hemisphere of governments accused of committing crimes against humanity. 

The Ortega–Murillo couple framed the decision as a commitment to “reconciliation and peace,” as dozens of detainees were freed from prison facilities. A preliminary assessment determined that between 19 and 30 of those released were in fact political prisoners, including politician Óscar Gadea and evangelical pastor Rudy Palacios. 

Opposition leaders argued that Managua was yielding to what they described as the “Maduro factor,” following the capture of the Bolivarian leader in Caracas and his transfer to New York along with his wife to stand trial, where a life sentence is widely expected. 

This context, they say, explains the Ortegas’ sudden decision. “There is no doubt that this is the result of political pressure and of chess moves triggered by events in Venezuela,” the Unión Democrática Renovadora (Unamos) said. 

The U.S. State Department has long questioned the legal mandate of the Ortega–Murillo regime following flawed elections in which most opposition leaders were either imprisoned or forced into exile. The Bureau of Western Hemisphere Affairs noted that Ortega’s 2006 election should have resulted in a single five-year term, not a nearly two-decade-long dynasty. 

“Today, the brutal Murillo–Ortega dictatorship ‘celebrates’ 19 years of what should have been a five-year democratic mandate. Nicaraguans voted for a president in 2006, not for an illegitimate dynasty for life,” the State Department said in a statement, as Washington enforces its “zero tolerance” policy toward full democratization. 

Among political analysts, the prevailing question is no longer “if,” but rather “who’s next,” as attention increasingly turns toward Cuba.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Mexican president tells Trump that US intervention against cartels is ‘unnecessary’
entry:
Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said she had “a very good conversation” with U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday and that their two governments will continue working together on security issues without the need for U.S. intervention against drug cartels. 

The approximately 15-minute call came after Sheinbaum said Friday that she had requested dialogue with the Trump administration at the end of a week in which Trump said he was ready to confront drug cartels on the ground and repeated accusations that cartels were running Mexico. 

Trump has repeatedly offered to send the U.S. military after the cartels, an option Sheinbaum has consistently declined. However, following the U.S. removal of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, Trump’s comments about Mexico, Cuba and Greenland carried new weight. 

“He asked me my opinion about what they had done in Venezuela and I told him very clearly that our constitution is very clear, that we do not agree with interventions and that was it,” Sheinbaum said. 

Trump “still insisted that if we ask for it, they could help” with military forces, which Sheinbaum said she again rejected. “We told him, so far it’s going very well, it’s not necessary, and furthermore there is Mexico’s sovereignty and territorial integrity and he understood,” she said. 

In an interview with Fox News aired last Thursday, Trump said, “We’ve knocked out 97% of the drugs coming in by water and we are going to start now hitting land, with regard to the cartels. The cartels are running Mexico. It’s very sad to watch.” 

Sheinbaum said Monday that the two leaders agreed to continue working together. 

Mexico’s Foreign Affairs Secretary Juan Ramón de la Fuente spoke Sunday with U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio. Rubio asked for “tangible results” and greater cooperation to dismantle the cartels, according to a statement from the U.S. State Department. 

Sheinbaum said Mexico shared such results, including a significant drop in homicides, falling U.S. fentanyl seizures and a decrease in fentanyl overdose deaths. 

Experts consider direct U.S. intervention in Mexico unlikely, given Mexico’s cooperation and its importance as an economic partner, but expect Trump to continue using such rhetoric to maintain pressure on Mexico to intensify its efforts.
author: Gregoria Verity

headline: Honduras rejects ‘illegal’ recount order of vote won by Trump-backed Nasry Asfura (AFP, 13 January)
entry:
Honduras’s electoral authorities rejected on Monday an order by the outgoing president to recount November’s election won by Trump-backed candidate Nasry Asfura. 

Asfura, a conservative businessman, was declared the winner of Honduras’s presidential election on December 24, weeks after a tight race marred by delays and allegations of fraud. 

Outgoing President Xiomara Castro, who leaves office on January 27, called last week for a meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump, arguing that his public backing of Asfura had “negatively influenced” the election, and demanded a recount of the vote. 

The head of the National Electoral Council (CNE), which oversees elections in Honduras, said in a statement posted on social media on Monday that the recount decree was “unconstitutional and illegal,” adding that it sought to “usurp” the independence of the electoral authority. 

The U.S. State Department’s Bureau of Western Hemisphere Affairs also warned on Saturday that “attempts to illegally overturn Honduras’s election will have serious consequences.” 

Secretary of State Marco Rubio met with Asfura in Washington on Monday, where they discussed “the importance of combating transnational crime, strengthening regional security, attracting new investment opportunities, and ending illegal immigration,” according to the State Department. 

Asfura, a 67-year-old businessman and son of Palestinian immigrants, narrowly defeated opposition Liberal Party candidate Salvador Nasralla, a conservative television personality, by 40.1% to 39.5% in the presidential race.

The European Union released this statement today: “The EU expresses its concern regarding the recent decree and the statements by President Xiomara Castro and the president of the Congress, calling for a recount of the 2025 general election held on 30 November 2025. The EU reiterates its support for the work of the Honduran electoral institutions and the official proclamation of results by the National Electoral Council, which recognised Nasry Asfura as the country’s legitimate president-elect and confirmed the final results for the National Congress and municipal elections. The EU condemns the acts of violence carried out against political actors in recent days and calls on all actors to ensure a peaceful and orderly transition of power. The will of the Honduran people, clearly expressed through the electoral process, must be respected. We look forward to working with President Asfura and his administration." 

The EU statement strengthens international support for the National Electoral Council’s results and further weakens President Xiomara Castro’s call for a recount. By recognizing Asfura as the legitimate president-elect and expressing willingness to work with his administration, the EU signals that contesting the election results is unlikely to gain international backing, echoing Washington’s position and raising the political cost for Castro and her allies.
author: Gregoria Verity
